* My favorite is that the day after the nearby cafe burned down, these guys Raised Prices!! * It's the most expensive coffee in the Haight.

Honestly, despite being a somewhat regular customer (at least after the good cafe burned to the ground), I was never once warmly greeted, and although the woman (I assume sister) would be somewhat cordial, there's something genuinely chemically wrong with the guy. He doesn't blink. He doesn't smile. There's no emotion. He obviously doesn't care about the products, the store or the customers. 

There's something wrong going on here, and it looks like a lot other recent Yelpers agree.
author: Cam M.

description:
After a day of exploring the stores along Haight-Ashbury and meandering into Golden Gate Park, we decided to stop for something to bite the cold.  Coffee to the People reminds me of one of the coffee shops at my alma mater in Boulder, Colorado.  Whether you spend a few minutes or a few hours, time is not what matters here.  

We took a couple of seats towards the front of the place as we waited for our drinks.  I've definitely had better coffee, and I felt a little skimped by the volume of foam in my Americano.  They offer some lite bites and pastries, but we didn't want to ruin our appetite for dinner.  Since I was on vacation and I feeling generous, I'll give Coffee to the People three stars--this is based predominantly on the vibe of the place.

It transported mind back to my college days.  Students were busy studying all around us, surrounded by textbooks and laptops.  Others were drawing in their sketchbooks or contemplating their plans for the upcoming night.  It's pleasing to know that there are coffee shops that can emulate a sense of home and welcoming.  It's not the nicest place in the world, but it gets the job done.
author: Sarah K.

description:
* "Democracy is a muscle; use it or lose it!"
* "Has anyone seen my constitutional rights?"
* "Your silence will not protect you."
* "Peace is patriotic."

Who needs a book of inspirational quotes when you've got a whole wall covered in them to choose from??

Though I sort of felt like I had chosen to work on my JET application at a place that reminded me a little too much of my college cafeteria, I actually did end up using some of the politically-fueled quotations from the bumper stickers I read on the wall in the essay I had come there to write. I opened up my "statement of purpose" by describing the details of the place in which I sat. Which was--duh--a coffee shop, BUT, is really just a microcosm of its larger context.

San Francisco.

Ahhh, my San Francisco...

Coffee to the People is both a cliche and a love song to the city it's in. After all, it is located all of 2 blocks from the famed Haight and Ashbury intersection. Students and their teachers seem to be the main clientele here, where they meet to work on papers, unabashedly trade liberal ideas and discuss the theoretical aesthetics of commercial architecture, and enjoy a good ol' cup-a-Joe (or tea, in my case! Tea to the People, too!).

On the minuses, it's a bit noisy, some of the people here can be a bit smelly, and I wouldn't recommend leaving your laptop unattended for even a second. But... it is just *so* San Francisco. And as much as I'm crossing my fingers to get into this program to teach English in Japan for a couple of years, if I leave I will dearly miss places like this. In this city that has inspired me to do much more with my life.

Awww, I love San Francisco! *tear*
author: Kate V.

description: I've been in several times before and the staff has always been friendly. I typically just get an iced coffee and they are consistent. This time I asked for a recommendation from the barista. It was evening so I didn't want too much caffeine. Matthew recommended the Mint Macha Mocha. It was perfect!! The flavors blended very smooth together. Its a great little evening pick me up which I needed after a long day of work. I also recommend the vegetarian lasagna, but please leave me some. =)
author: Janelle K.

description: I live just across the street (on Haight), and unfortunately the closest Starbucks to my place is 10 minutes away (Fulton/Stanyan). Luckily this place is a good replacement. I've never eaten anything there, but their coffee is good (I'd say 8/10) and I highly recommend it (my favorites are latte and coffee mocha). Interior looks cheap, but if you want to stay there instead of taking your coffee to go, they have a huge selection of books you can read there, or board games you can play.
author: Igor P.

description:
Love hummus on my sandwich. Do not love flies near my coffee. You get a little of both at the Haight institution Coffee To The People.

Compared to other yelpers, I'm in the minority on this one, just wasn't that impressed. Service was friendly, and my sandwich was good (appreciated that hummus). But it was a bit more expensive than similar sandwiches elsewhere. And the most memorable thing about the coffee was the flies near the milk and cream station.

Sorry CTTP, I've had better elsewhere.
author: Jason B.

description: This is my favorite coffee shop in the Haight. Tons of seating, free WiFi, great coffee, great customer service. They even have board games and books.
author: Benjamin R.

description: Friendly staff and great menu options! I'm a big fan of their hummus bagel special. They also have a lot of coffee and tea drinks for a morning or afternoon pick me up. A great neighborhood spot!
author: AC R.

description: The typical haight ambiance that you'd expect (which is awesomeeeeee). Chill, late area, plenty of tables and outlets, and the staff is so sweet! The internet is fast as well. I'll be back :)
author: Sandy C.

description:
I can't imagine Coffee to the People being located in any other neighborhood than the Haight. It is a very hip coffee shop and as you walk in you'll notice a ton of people reading books, playing board games or working on their laptops. They layout of the space is very open and I get the feeling that some people will spend their entire weekend here (which can become frustrating if you're looking for a table).

The coffee is tasty and whenever I'm on Haight and Masonic I tend to stop in here for some fresh coffee.
author: Bryan B.

description: I LOVE this place!!!! The coffee was delicious! We stayed in San Francisco for a few days and this became our "go to" spot for our morning breakfast and coffee. Everything we had here each day was delicious! The croissants were delicious!!! Large, flaky, buttery, fresh, and soft every time! The egg breakfast sandwiches tasted fresh and made from a grill rather than a microwave. The people who work here go out of their way to make sure you are satisfied and happy. The mini cinnamon rolls were so very tasty!!! The atmosphere is laid-back and chill....just a perfect coffee shop vibe. I wish this place was down the street from my home because I would definitely go back everyday!!!
author: Andrea G.

description:
Latte was great. Bagel not so much... But maybe bagels aren't a thing here. Kind of wanted to buy a second cup of coffee to throw at the barista... but I was there for caffiene not good service.

Overall - I was whelmed. Not over... not under... just whelmed.
author: Brian M.

description: Cool place to chill and have free WiFi ! They also have non diary milk to add to coffee for vegan.
author: Alice K.

description: Good, reasonably priced coffee. Couches and plenty of seating. Free wifi and outlets. Here's the problem: I would come here more often, but every time I've been here bums and hippies come in and stink up the place. I wouldn't care, but they reek and I can't stand the smell. They sit on the couches and I can't help but think that the smell gets into the couches. The owners should do something to keep them out. Not good for business.
author: Jordan G.

description: A very enjoyable atmosphere. Low-key energy: chill on their sofas and accommodating seating while looking at some rare photography and art. They have a awesome library of various types of intriguing literature. The service is acommodating and the folks are very friendly.
author: Collin C.

description:
They serve organic, fair trade, locally roasted coffee - which pretty much gets them four stars right there.  Not to mention their display case of pastries including the raspberry swirl cheese cake with a chocolate cookie crumb crust, amazing.  
Also have artwork, by a talented neighborhood fiber artist for sale in the back.  Great pieces that I yearn for.
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place had decent coffee and tea. The clientele was a bit seedy, but it was during festival time so that was to be expected with homeless people trying to work their way in and all. I saw they had some good vegetarian options as well.
author: Bob B.

description: Iced Mocha coffee is a little watery but tasted alright. Heard another patron complain about hers being too watery. The lounge areas are nice and have good enough space to be comfortable with your group.
author: JD H.

description: Had a great coffee and cakes on a busy Saturday shopping on the Haight, nice clean bathroom too, was good place to escape the crowds...
author: Simon W.

description:
Coffee to the People is justly named ~ it supports fair trade coffee, encourages sustainable disposables, but offers choices - i.e. whether to take or return a coffee sleeve, use a wooden stirrer or a clean (or dirty, if preferred) metal spoon.

I enjoy their full bodied-black coffee. I've also tried their dessert bread - blueberry cornbread and almond croissant - yum! They have a nice variety of pastries (selection changes, it's sort of a surprise) and savories. 

Very comfortable space with ample seating, high ceiling and free wi-fi. Local artwork displayed and for sale long the walls.

A people-friendly place.
author: Cathy K.

description:
The Good:  Free WiFi, ample seating with couches and tables, pretty good service.
The Bad:  Difficult parking, homeless come inside and hang out until they are asked if they are going to buy something.

So I came in here to do some reading and do some work on my laptop.  I found a comfy couch with a big table I could set up my laptop in front of me on.  I ordered a drink and sat down to get working.  A young couple consisting of a bohemian 20-something hippie chick and a thuggish dude with a hoodie came in and sat down next to me and proceeded to take over most of the table.  Cell phone and charger plugged in and on the table and a chess board set up on the table.  No biggie I could probably still find a space in the corner for my laptop or I could use it on my lap.

I noticed the girl had a constant cough that sounded rather strange - like there was a lot of phlegm in her throat.  The guy said nothing the whole time and only seemed to get agitated when his female friend would beat him in chess.  There clothes looked a little bit ratty and I thought that they might be homeless but they didn't smell or have any obviously bad hygiene so I figured they were your garden variety Haight St. hippies.  

Then out of the blue, a barrista asked them if they were going to order something.  I think the girl wanted to stay and she said "ummmm......" while the guy muttered "no mas" and started getting up to leave.  I guess that was his signal to his friend that they had to leave so they left.

On another couch there was an obese man with a white beard who was clearly homeless.  He left on his own after hanging out for a short while so he must have known what he could get away with in terms of hanging out without buying stuff.
author: Mark G.

description:
Plenty of space, comfortable seating, easy access power outlets, free wifi, friendly service, good selection of coffees, teas, and pastries.    Really has all the bases covered well.  

Reading through the other reviews, it seems the only negative is the occasional  presence of odoriferous customers / street people.  The few times I've been here I haven't run into that (maybe I've been lucky) so I give this place 5 stars.
author: XiuCe H.

description:
I read some of the negative reviews before writing this, because I am curious and cynical. Many reviewers seemed to think that this was a yuppie hangout. To the contrary, this seems to be one of the only coffee shops that is yuppieless. 

Maybe some reviewers are not good at spotting yuppies, so I'll give you a quick overview (I lived in Palo Alto for three horrible months, so I know my way around them). Yuppiehood requires the following characteristics: 

1. Zero critical thinking abilities beyond technocratic and fiduciary wisdom.
2. An expectation that inflated prices equal quality, and a preternatural attraction to places that exemplify expensive tastes.
3. A feigned interest in "diversity" which hides a true disdain for any socioeconomic diversity.
3a. A physical repulsion for poverty, despite a democratic voting record.
4. A boring personality.

Okay, now back to CTTP.

I find myself strangely drawn back here, time and time again. I should say as a disclaimer I am about as far as one could get from being a coffee snob. I have no idea what good or bad coffee is, and I don't really understand the hype over comparing cafés for their coffee.

That being said, I AM a tea snob, and I do understand what good and bad tea is. Coffee To the People has a truly phenomenal tea selection--two different kinds of oolong? Seriously. And the prices are GOOOOOD. The baristas give you a bag of looseleaf tea exploding out of the paper teabag for less than two bucks, and hot water after that's free. Often their overpacked tea bags are good for two refills.

Anyway, I think the best part of CTTP is the couches. I said I was a tea snob. Add to my snobbery a couch snobbery. Not with brand, but with comfort. I love the couches here because they are plentiful and plush and always seem to have room for another tookus. 

It's also a really interesting café to sit and people-watch. The people who come in and out are really truly diverse-socioeconomically, that is. I like a café where rich, poor and inbetween interact. The local street kids and beggars seem to have this innate respect for Coffee to the People--they don't bother people inside for change, or beg outside, and the owners treat them with just as much respect as customers as they do anyone else.

Finally, the quality of light by the skylights is really good, and there are a ton of books on the wall. If you're ever bored, there's no shortage of weird books on the wall to peruse. The diversity of books is also very strange--on a recent visit, I saw a book on typography, an autobiography of J. Edgar Hoover, a book on investing by Chuck Schwab and Jonathan Franzen's The Corrections. Weird.

PS: If you say CTTP with a slur, it sounds like CCCP. "I'm going down to Soviet Russia for coffee and prole-watching."
author: Maxine Y.

description:
Crappy coffee, smells like homeless people, bad incense and unwashed hair...authentic experience of the haight i guess, but a pretty crap coffee shop - why 3 1/2 stars yelp why? 

I used to live w blocks from here and, needless to say i only tried it once...walk the extra couple blocks to Cole valley cafe @ cole and waller (the only good coffee in upper haight).
author: Krista H.

description: I love Coffee to the People! So coool! Very boho vibe but I wish the music was more retro like the beatles, It would complete the 60's illusion. It will be old school hippie mecca.
author: Dom R.

description:
This place was suuper crowded on the Saturday afternoon that I came.  But I'm going to rate this place on its coffee and its coffee is good!  I got regular coffee because that's how you can tell good from bad coffee beans.  The taste was really memorable, probably one of the best tasting coffees I've had in Cali.  It's also free trade and organic coffee, which is the big thing nowadays.

They have a lot of different coffees too.  My friend got this coffee with matcha green tea and chocolate syrup... I thought it was really good but she's not much of a coffee drinker so she didn't really enjoy it that much.
author: Angela C.

description:
Good atmosphere and people, but the chai latte isn't that great.
Wi-Fi connection is good enough, but bumped me off once each time I've been.
author: David G.

description:
Coffee to the People makes me sad.  No, the coffeehouse itself isn't sad or depressing, and I actually really like coming here and supporting the little guy.  But one of the original owners of Coffee to the People was once a coworker of mine, so when I used to come here, I used to know the little guy--er, gal--I was supporting.

The space itself is a good combination of cramped, lived-in, and inviting.  I don't drink coffee, so I can't comment on that end of it, but the hot chocolate is mighty good.

I don't know the new owners at all, so I don't know anything about their employment practices, but last time I was here, I asked about my friend (the former owner), and the worker told me that she had sold the business more than a year ago.  Again, that made me sad, but I was also happy to know that this person had been around long enough to know whom I was talking about, and I had only said, "Is _____ here?"  I didn't have to specify which _____, and it's a pretty common name.

I guess I'll get over my sadness, and it's wonderful to have a great place to hang out in the Haight.  It's also a bonus that it's not right on Haight Street, but I sometimes wonder how many people hear about Coffee to the People and end up (tragically) at the People's Cafe.

UPDATE:  5/28/12
==============

Maybe they should call it Coffee to the People Who Don't Use Wheelchairs, because wheelchair users can't come inside.  Where's the disability-rights love, C to the P?  Minus one star for you!
author: John S.

description:
Two caffeinated thumbs up.  This is the ideal place to come and study - they don't mind lingering, have lots of seating, and it's a hodgepodge of characters.  As for the people who mentioned homeless folks hanging out there in their reviews - it's true.  But wouldn't it be hypocritical for a coffee shop that encourages community NOT to allow them to stay?  True, you never know who you're gonna meet  -- but that's part of the adventure.  
Also true - there are more delicious places in S.F. to get coffee, but the laid-back atmosphere here makes it what it is.  If you're getting a drip blend, I recommend the Peace and Love Alliance.  Now how's that for Haight St.?  Their espresso drinks are quality.  This place has officially become my thesis writing haven...and there's enough going on inside to provide much needed distractions from time to time.
author: Brooke N.

description: Delicious coffee. Just stumbled on this place while wandering around the area and had a very delicious coffee there. Nice cozy atmosphere great place to be on your computer or just kill time and drink a coffee.
author: Mandy B.

description:
Walking home from The Booksmith, I was getting quite chilly because the sun had just set and apparently 3 layers don't keep me warm anymore. So I opted for a nice hot chocolate to warm me up.

Coffee to the People is relatively big for a cafe; it has a bunch of small tables to eat at and then has like 4 or 5 couches towards the back where you can relax and read one of the many books they already have on the shelves (if you've forgotten to bring your own.) I also noticed a book case full of board games? I wonder if those ever get used...

The decor is rather simple, to the point where it even seems a bit drab. They definitely could use some artwork on that mustard-colored wall! I do like that they serve organic products though. Maybe next year they'll be on Green Zebra and I can add them to the list.

Other than that, the hot cocoa with whipped cream hit the spot!

Total: $2.50
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Really eclectic place...very mellow atmosphere. Staff was super friendly and funny. Tried one of their drink specials (I forget the name but it was a hot chai-espresso blend) SUPER strong and yummy! Exactly what I wanted. =)

Fairly large inside as well, lots of space to sit and do whatever. Loved looking at all the art all over the walls too.

Overall, Great Experience.
author: Meredith M.

description:
I've been coming here off and on for four years (depends on if I'm trying to kick the coffee habit or if I've accepted my caffeine dependency as a natural part of graduate school) and I've always been pleased with my experience.

The coffee/ espresso drinks are a step above Starbucks or Peets, but still a notch down from Blue Bottle.  They carry your regular coffee shop pastries and a lot of tasty vegan options.  I'm not a vegan, but like many SF foodies I'll try almost anything once. 

The staff is friendly. I'm a regular so I never see any of the attitude that others have mentioned. I should note, however, that this is not the place to grab a coffee if you are in a hurry.  The staff here takes time to talk to people and make a good cup of coffee.  Unless there is no one in line, you're going to need a couple of extra minutes to get your coffee.

The clientele is diverse.  There are yuppies and street kids, but mainly just locals who have accepted this diversity as the norm.  This mix of people can be fun if you are chilling out on a Sunday morning, but not if you are trying to get serious work done.

BONUS TIP:  Sunday mornings can get packed here.  So if you're looking to nab a table, arrive early. 

BONUS TIP #2:  If you like bad art, the selection here changes monthly.  It's a pretty amusing topic of conversation.
author: Lara O.

description: Coffee to the People does a decent coffee and a nice, spicy chai latte.  Friendly service too.  Worth deviating slightly off Haight Street if you feel like a drink.
author: Mary S.

description: Good place to sit down read or go on the computer while having your coffee. The coffee is kind of expensive. I did like the fact that my Mocha was not super hot in that I drank it up right away. Just OK.
author: Paul V.

description: It smells like pee in here. Otherwise good prices, good selection, free wifi, good space to hang out.
author: Cate L.

description:
I would give five stars if they would close this place for a day and give it a good scrub.  And replace the B.O.-infused couches with fresh ones.  And institute a slightly stricter policy with regards to homeless people spending hours here.  I recently saw it Twittered, too, by someone I hardly know: "Coffee to the People is basically a homeless shelter."  Most of the people in my apartment building, on Haight and Masonic, have a ban on CTTP, having followed too many optimistic impulses to spend a few hours here, only to run out choking on clouds of assiness.  Me, I can't help but come occasionally, convenience factor and all, but god, I would be here all the time if it just didn't stink so bad!  

I don't think it's cause for hygiene concerns in the kitchen -- the people who work here seem too normal to be suffering this stench -- it's just out here in the trenches, the tables and the couches, where the guy next to me has puss oozing out of his scalp, and the back of the couch glistens with the shine of hair grease.  I know there's a whole hippie theme going on in this place, and that's cool, and maybe you feel like the stink/homelessness is part of the atmosphere, but are the hippies really the ones buying your lattes?  Come on, clean it up!  Please!  We could even have a neighborhood CTTP cleaning day.  I would totally pitch in.
author: Holly B.

description:
I only visit in the AM, so these are the staff I know.  They are indeed very, very nice and attentive folks.  When they first took over from the prior ownership, I had found *some* of the new staff to be quite off putting and downright unfriendly.  These new guys are great.

Nice space, well appointed and large.  Cool artwork and decorations on the wall.  I'd say it's the best laid-out and homey cafe in the whole neighborhood.

However, recently, I have found the invasion by numerous sorts of "street-type"  people to impart such a foul, rank aroma in the air that often I can not even stay for a moment.  I have seen the place completely cleared out by even just one or two over-ripe individuals. Sometimes there are many more.   I find it totally nauseating.  I know this may pose a difficult issue for management and the staff, but I think they are going to have to make a choice as to who their client base will be.

Except tor the above, I would go for five stars.  However, three is the best I can offer-  put CTTP on your agenda for the day, but be prepared to quickly move on to an alternate venue.
author: Anthony G.

description: One of the only places in my area(Nopa) that offers almond milk(for those of you primal eaters who can't have dairy or soy). The place is a little rough looking, and you do have to make your way thru the local Haight street homeless crew out front, but non the less, the staff is super friendly and FAST. The truth is, I'm addicted to matte latte's which are made from Yerba Matte green tea instead of coffee. They are hard to find in the city, let alone made with almond milk. Coffee in a hurry from a friendly staff is definitely a 4 star place in my book!
author: Tatum T.

description:
I stumbled across this place while looking at a room across the street.

Their coffee is awesome, as is the free wifi, but the 5 star rating is for their breakfast sandwich. OK, it's not exactly NY pricing (I'm still searching for the place that has 2 eggs on a roll with small coffee for under $2) but for around $5, you get a monster egg sandwich on a bagel that should cover you straight through to dinnertime.

I love their logo and suggested they make up shirts to sell.  Oddly,
they seem to have never thought of this idea.  If you insist, you can mail me my free shirt.  Or, better yet, I'll swing by for breakfast!
author: dan s.

description:
Delicious coffee.  The coffee is Fair Trade which means the coffee growers get a fair price for their beans, they don't get ripped off.  They have vegan donuts made in Berkeley and delivered between 4 and 6pm.  I love the vegan donuts.  I am totally addicted.  I tried the vegan spice carrot cake and it was a bit dry, but yummy.  

This is a cool coffee shop.  A good hangout if you live close to it.  these people stand up for worthy causes and that is awesome.  Support this place, they have good morals and excellent cawfee.

Only bad thing I could say is that it seemed a little dirty.  Probably because people are always hanging out inside all day long and eating.  newspapers all over the place, etc.  The bathroom was clean.  Staff was nice.  I love this place.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Stopped by here when I was shopping to get something warm to sip and hold on to. (Awkward pause...) In any case, it was very spacious and I immediately thought "this definitely looks like a place I would enjoy studying or writing in". It reminded me of a similar place in Seattle...

But I digress. I read some of the signs while waiting (there were about 5 people ahead of me, but I didn't wait crazy long) and saw some great offerings, including the option of several different kinds of milk (almond, rice, soy...some others). Love that! I had just about lost my voice that weekend and the cashier was very patient with me and leaned in attentively as I attempted to enunciate my order. So +1 star for not making feel foolish! 

I can't judge them on anything but some super legit hot chocolate and friendly service (then again what more do you need)... but I'd definitely stop by more if I was in the area.
author: Cat M.

description: Any coffee shop that has plush couches, a bookshelf full of various games, artwork featured by local artists and delightful coffee is alright in my book. Though I don't frequent the Haight all that often I can honestly say I would venture out to CTTP if I had a good book, some yelp reviews to catch up on my lap top, or I was just looking for a fun and relaxing change of scenery. There's just such a great vibe and energy to the place that you can't help but loose yourself in. I dig this place...... a lot.
author: Kristy M.

description: Yeah!!! Nice strong coffee!  Great spacious woody cafe.  Plenty of seating and free wifi!  Very cozy place to study or do work.  They serve lunch and their coffee is Really strong.    Great friendly staff. Best Coffee shop in the Haight!
author: Ying F.

description:
The things I do to procrastinate.

Scratch my butt.  

Give my cat a bath.

Give myself a bath.

Sing Guns n' Roses in said bath.

Write Yelp reviews.

I should be writing other things.  It's Nanowrimo time again and while I feel like I'm at a good place with 6,014 words, I need to be diligent and keep at it. This is why I'm AT CTTP in the first place.  I wanna leave this place 10,000 words strong.  Coffee.  Coffee will help.  And doughnut.  Vegan doughnut will help.  

Why does this place rock?  They offer Soy, Hazelnut, Almond AND Rice Milk.  They have Tofutti Cream Cheese for their bagels!  They have vegan donuts as well as other various vegan baked goods (though I must say the cookies looked a little sad.)

The staff was pretty nice and not surly at all and I didn't have to fight for a spot on a couch near an outlet like you have to do at other places.
author: Jen I.

description: Big fan but sort of hot while I was in there. Food tried: Cheese Bagel with Cream Cheese (must eat), Almond Croissant (delicious). Coffee: White Mocha Coffee was amazing.
author: Dorian S.

description:
Went inside here on a whim because I couldn't find any other restroom on Haight. Ran inside, quickly ordered a vegan chocolate chip cookie and  vanilla creme frap then ran inside the bathroom. Wait a minute, no I couldn't run inside, there were three men in line before me. The lack of public restrooms in this area makes many turn to coffeeshops like these. Like me. Anyway, after I went, I came out and got my bready, cinnamony choco cookie which was tasty and sipped on my cold vanilla creme. 

It was very crowded, with most people on their laptops, or reading, and a bit dirty too, with leftover cups on the side and trash on the ground. 
It definitely isn't the coolest coffeeshop I've been too, and rather plain, but thanks for bathroom, man.  

Oh, and the people there looks like your typical, bookish type with those square rimmed glasses. Hawt.
author: Amy F.

description:
The coffee is pretty good here and it seems like a good place to go and have a good chat with a group of people or one on one. 

downside, the staff wasn't very friendly and the entrance is filled with street wanderers. Doesn't make the place very approachable.

Probably wouldn't go again.
author: Brandon D.

description:
I don't actually get coffee here (tea, please). I come for the comfy chairs, free internet, mildly-overpriced-but-good cafe food, and great people watching. Even if the servers can be unnecessarily standoffish, it's a generally mellow spot. Good place to meet with friends or get work done, though I probably wouldn't recommend doing any heavy reading here. 

Things I WOULD recommend:
1. The bagel with hummus (they don't mess around). Smothered. with. hummus.
2. Buddha Blend tea: perfect. It just is.
3. PEOPLE WATCHING. In the past five minutes, the following people have passed me: Tall skinny guy with tight denim shorts and an enormous red beard; petite girl with quirky bangs and full sleeve tats carrying a giant power rangers backpack; a group of tall slender people projecting "irony" and all things hip running to grab the scrabble board; a sweet older couple chatting about Greek mythology (you get the picture).

Not my favorite in the city, but probably your best bet for a coffee shop on Haight. Plus, you'll be supporting an independent establishment instead of Starbucks, and I'm fond of the anti-corporate, "down with the man!" feel of this place.

Edit: Updated from 3 to 4 stars, only because I keep coming back here... they must be doing something right.
author: Sam S.

description:
I guess I am a coffee snob... I am fine with that.  But one should not have to explain to the barista why you prefer your espresso in an espresso cup and the cold, crema-less shot he just dumped out from a paper cup is not going to work.  He would not remake my drink and instead gave me an espresso cup full of drip coffee.  Fail.

They stopped doing individual prepared "hand crafted" (Chemex) coffee, because "it was too much work".  Just large batch drip coffee in thermal dispenser pots now.
author: Wade T.

description:
Not much to say about this quaint, yet notable establishment. I had originally stopped in to use the restroom during one of my many strolls around haight, and decided that I was in the mood for coffee. Me drinking coffee is hardly a rare occurrence, but I dont usually get it by itself when I eat out. I did on this occasion though, as I had planned for lunch at the always fabulous Blue Front Cafe later on. 

I had taken the time to take in the cafe before ordering, though. Very cozy. Ample, comfortable tables and seating. Books and flyers and all sorts of great decor. A somewhat small yet impressive looking selection of treats on display at the counter, such as vegan donuts, marble cakes, muffins, cookies, etc. As well as some more savory items, like a veggie lasagna and quiche, and plenty of breads. 

My order was oh-so-simple. A medium cup of black coffee. It came out in a very uniform looking mug with a small plate under it. A nice touch, I thought. The coffee itself was piping hot and an awesome pick me up. Great roast. Great flavor. I sipped it at a table and enjoyed the intermission to my shopping and sampling spree. 

Next time ill have to try one of their vegan donuts with my coffee. Im sure its a winning combination. 

Recommended, even if its just for a cup of black gold.
author: A K.

description:
While on a bike ride, I stopped in for a much needed caffeine refueling before climbing back up to twin peaks.  Got a small cup of black coffee. It was good. Not amazing, not terrible. It was A-Ok.  

I would have given 4 stars for the coffee but the service was pretty scowly. I mean, its a nice day out...would it kill you to smile at your customers?
author: Nilu r.

description:
**downgraded to 1 star because I treid to give them another chance and was AGAIN treated crappily. Skip this place**

Coffee's okay here, but the service stinks!!

I live in the neighborhood and decided to go camp out, do some work, and eat my way through their menu.

I waited patiently in line at the counter, and when I was next up, the cashier decided to make us line up in a different direction. Everyone complied, but since I was next, I just stood where I was, assuming that he saw me and not wanting to lose my spot in line while the rest of the line jockeyed for position.

When I stepped up to the register, the cashier ignored me, even though I was standing right in front of him and had been for maybe 5 minutes. "You're just going to ignore me?" I asked.
"Yup," he said.

Oooooookayyyy. There are a lot of places to get a cup of coffee in the Haight where they practice basic human courtesy. I don't see any reason why I should go back to CTTP.
author: Andrea S.

description: Space is clean and large with plenty of seats and tables. The back of the room has couches and a good sized library of books for you to just chill in. Service is friendly and fast, no complaints there. Free wifi with no password and interesting decor makes this kind of a nice relaxing place to just chill or study. The hot chocolate (only thing I've tried so far) isn't very sweet and kind of drab, but the rest more than makes up for it. And they're one of the few places on Haight even open early in the morning so five stars from me!
author: John N.

description: This place should be renamed "Coffee to the Walking Upright People Only". Sorry, but after getting up the hill to the entrance in my manual wheelchair, I want to be able to actually get into the place I'm trying to go. It's not wheelchair accessible and the description should not say it is.
author: Rhiannon L.

description: Wow! I am so happy I found this cute little place! Right when you walk in you can just feel the chill & mellow atmosphere. They have some must on the menu & everything looked so good I didn't know what to get but I ended up getting the lemon essence tea. I recommend it if your a tea lover! Oh & they have free wifi which is a plus. But the only complaint I had was the bathroom wasn't the cleans but other then that I would have given it 5 stars!
author: Alexandra A.

description: Great coffee, friendly service, opened before 6!!!
author: Deanna W.

description: I ducked into coffee to the people to get out of the overcrowded Haight St. The atmosphere is cute and cozy and is a good place to take a break from the tourist packed Haight-Ashbury district. However I didn't really like my vanilla almond milk latte as it was a bit ground-y and tasted burnt. My boyfriend enjoyed his regular vanilla latte, but agreed that mine tasted awful. We did experience a little spat between someone trying to use the restroom and a staff member. The barista was a little rude, but in her defense the customer had sworn at her under her breath. If I was in the area again, it wouldn't be on the top of my list, but it wasn't an awful experience. .
author: Crystal R.

description:
Being a local, I don't venture to the tourist spots that often, but we were in the neighborhood and I was hankering for my morning coffee.  After walking for a bit, I see "COFFEE TO THE PEOPLE" calling to me.  Yes, coffee!!!

I go to order my usual drink (double iced espresso), and I see the barista used the smallest cup, so I asked for a bigger cup.  This is when I got attitude...

Barista: "WELL I can't do that!"
Me: "umm ok?"
Barista:  "I have to charge you for a larger size"
Me:  "that's fine, whatever."
Barista:  "Because it's just WRONG when people get iced espressos and add more milk.  They're getting a latte at no extra charge"
Me:  *blank stare*

THIS is pretentious.  Yes, I want to add my own milk, but I don't want a watered down latte, I like a splash of milk and cream.  And what the hell, like they're not making enough money off my $3 double espresso.  Doesn't it cost like 10 cents to make???  Oh sorry, don't forget to add the 10 cent cup.  

Attitudes like that are why I go to Starbucks.  If I pay for a product, I will consume it the way I like, not the way a snobby barista says I should, even if the coffee is good.
author: Rachael J.

description:
Good place for delicious fair trade coffee and a cozy atmosphere. They have plenty of seating, including sofas as well as a pretty good sized library. 

Overall a nice place to read on a rainy day. Just wish they didn't charge so much for soy milk. I don't get how it's free cold but 50-60 cents steamed?! If they really wanted to be coffee to the people, they'd recognize how many people (and ethnicities) cannot have dairy !
author: Sara W.

description: I actually loved this place.  The set up was great - there were tables, couches, books, etc.  Vintage, comfortable, unique - love it.  The selection (or at least the names of the selections) hold true to the vibe of the place, as my friend's unique mix of teas and coffee in one drink was called "flower power" or something fun like that!  I ended up getting a fairly large mango & blueberry smoothie, which was not overly priced.  Maybe I'm just used to the pricing of my school cafeteria which is ridiculously expensive but I was pleased with this place for sure :)
author: Rebecca D.

description:
So my mom was visiting. We had a really nice day shopping on Haight.
All was going well until...

We ordered from Coffee to the People. The girl at the counter had such attitude I couldn't believe it! I ordered a latte and then had to choose a milk- she looked at me like I was stupid and should know about all of the milk alternatives. Which obviously I didn't because I happen to normally drink regular milk. I ended up choosing hemp milk as a recommendation from the said barista ringing us up. Definitely not the best choice in my opinion.. I think i'll stick to regular milk from now on.

Now my mom drinks tea and this is what just set me off. The girl asked her what size tea she wanted. My mom asked if they charge different prices for the amount of water and the girl replied in a very rude tone:

"yes. we are not starbucks."

Ok Coffee to the People, I get it. You are an independent, super hippie, Starbucks hater coffee shop. But please, drop the attitude. Starbucks obviously has a good sales technique. If you buy tea, you should pay for the tea bag, not the amount of water.  I mean, c'moonnn.. Do you charge your customers for a glass of water? Yeah, I thought so.
author: Shayna B.

description:
Ever more do I love this cozy cafe......they blew me away yesterday with their orange cranberry loaf....it was a huge piece and so tasty with my Earl Grey tea that I had. The guy at the counter was so nice and friendly, asking how my day was going....

The vibe was mellow and inviting with 60's-ish wordless time-warped music playing in the background which allowed me to imagine what it could have been like to be here back in that day. Love it Love it! The manequin in the front window is a bit creepy however....
author: Lee M.

description:
Banana Mocha= Best. Thing. Ever.

Refreshing, chocolately, banana-y, and caffeinated. AMAZING!

Nice atmosphere-- can come to study or hang out. Really mellow.

Vegan friendly a Plus.
author: Crystal S.

description: After a couple of hours walking up and down Haight st, I was thirsty and in need of a restroom so I stopped in here. I had to buy something because you could only used the restroom if you bought something. I bought a sparkling water and a mini Cinnamon roll. This place seems like a nice quite place to do homework, read, meet friends or just to hang out. They have couches and wi-fi available. I guess the next time I am on the Haight, I'll have to give there coffee.
author: Kris O.

description: We have had some fun here.  A couple of years ago, our assiduous journeys to the City would frequently begin at Coffee to the People - before Haight Street shop-hopping and various quests for new spots.  Since I started working, we have less time for weekends in the City, and we've only been a couple of times in the past several months.   I see people writing about a change in mgmt.  I hadn't known about that as I prepared to write this review - but it does provide a possible reason for what I'm going to say.  I noticed a change.  The former eclectic clientele, the open, friendly vibe was missing - but more to the point, the deep richness of the coffee was missing  :?  It had gone from magic to mundane.  I hope to try again in the near-future - and hope to find old, singularly CTP vibe.  It's too cool a spot with great bones to lose.
author: Liana R.

description:
The coffee and food is average/good, the ambiance is cool, and the staff bugs me!

Not only do they shut the shop hours before the posted closing time, THEY TURN AWAY CUSTOMERS.

I was there one evening, and this guy asked if he could buy just some hot water, so he could make his own tea and sit and read. He even offered to pay the same price for the water as tea. Basically, they would make 3 bucks off this guy, but the guy behind the counter, who I think is the owner, got all uppity about it and refused him. Yet they allow random people off the street who aren't even customers to come in and use the bathroom. Huh.
author: Hannah J.

description:
I love the vibe of this place.  my first time here was luke-warm due to being helped by a fairly apathetic employee, but my subsequent visits were a lot better, thus it regained my confidence in this cafe :) 

what I like.. the playlist, the free wifi, lots of tables and places to sit, lots of posters and decor to look at (or get distracted by whilst studying), and they take credit card! (even though it has to be over $5)..  things not so liked.. the menu being slightly overpriced (but what do you expect from an organic/vegan shop?), and they close kinda early.  overall, great atmosphere, with mostly people working on their laptops and some chatters here and there.
author: Jennie L.

description: 12pm Sunday Afternoon, Great coffee shop. Lots of seats.  Lots of people on laptops. Quiet. Very quiet.  Beautiful countertops, lots of coffee house choices.  Italian sodas, lattes, Iced tea (green and black).  Big, clean bathroom.
author: Jean Z.

description:
Yep, there sure are a lot of political posters and slogans on the walls in here.  But given that this is the Haight, I can't help but wonder how much of it is an authentic feeling and how much of it is "hey, tour bus! over here! 60's agitator coffee!"  After all, plenty of SF coffee shops will put an extra shot of eco-socio-political agenda in your latte, and a rather more timely one at that.  My suggestion: C to the P needs to merge with the Anarchist Book Collective around the corner--now *that* would be a hard-core place to drink your latte while earnestly discussing the bankruptcy of capitalism.

Judged simply on its coffee-shop merits, C to the P is still solid, though neither the coffee nor atmosphere is, er...revolutionary.  But I'll tell you what is: hazelnut milk in your latte.  Light, silky, and delicious.  That stuff is totally the new almond milk.
author: Wes M.

description:
Used to go here all the time to get the Mate Lattes w/ Hazelnut Milk which are fucking amaaazinggg. Since I moved to the TNob I definitely don't get here as often as I'd like to. 

Overall, it's a cozy coffee joint that's great for studying with comfy seating, good music and free wi-fi. The drinks are a little on the more expensive side but that's to be expected in the gentrified Haight. 

I'm a little surprised about previous negative reviews on the "surly baristas." Everyone here has always been super friendly to me. Maybe cause I'm just friendly to them? Or maybe I just haven't noticed the unfriendly ones since I generally don't expect my baristas or whatever to be programmed overly-friendly robots? I dunno. I've worked as a barista before and its definitely difficult to smile and be pleasant to someone who is treating you like the person who makes them their coffee. It's not their job to give you a fake smile and pretend to be all chipper - go to a Starbucks or something if you really need that kind of validation from your Barista.
author: Tam G.

description: First off, I would like to put out there I *used* to be a fan of this place, but then they got new ownership.  The new owners came in, had the old staff train them, and then fired anyone who looked alternative (read:  anyone with unusual hair or visible tattoos).  The previous staff made it a point to know the regulars and their orders.  To greet us with a smile.  The new owners/staff seem to just want to make you a average cup of coffee, and get you out of there.  Not even a smile.  Plus the music is always just a titch too loud.
author: Tia B.

description:
Just the kind of old-school hippie social consciousness sort of place that makes me love living in San Francisco...

I love starting my day here, even just to run in and pick up a latte (which is reliably good). The walls are covered with cool left-wing quotes and pictures of heroic folk like Harriet Tubman and Ghandi -- a great way to ground in the morning and make a mental commitment to compassion and helpfulness as I start my day. They also have a library and a stack of board games, which I've never actually used, but are somehow nice to see.

Although I am not vegan myself, there seem to be a lot of vegan milk options and vegan/veg food items available. 

Oh, and here's what I really love -- they have compost and recycle waste bins available, and they also have a little picture of a garbage dump over their regular "landfill" garbage can. OK, I know that's a small thing, but it's effective.
author: Jen C.

description: Gonna come to set up cup of coffee there! ;-)
author: Alexander L.

description: The Haight-Ashbury suburb of San Francisco has played such a pivotal role in the history  of the this fine city, California, the USA, and indeed the World, not only in the recent past (1960s-70s) but since it's inception for the inhabitants. My wife & I took an LP-recommended walking tour of the area, which was quite fascinating, noting personalities from the turbulent times ('Grateful Dead" on the sidewalk!) but that persons from the upper stories of their homes watched the downtown SF burn in 1906. A long-time transplant from "back East" (which is everyplace because West is the wet Pacific) maintaining Buena Vista Park gave tidbits of information about this area, narrow & wide. Our place of recuperation  was inside this fine eatery. Like most of the establishments along a 2- or 3-block zone are carefully preserved to show the integrity of one of the older, more established neighborhoods, with local control and little outside corporate influence. Despite everything going digital--wifi is available here--the inhabitants exude a kindness and acceptance of all persons who show up, prepared or not for the harsh life required in this expensive city.
author: John E.

description:
Delicious soy chai latte!  It was great, just barely sweet and super frothy, yummyI

I can't say anything about the coffee because I didn't have any, but I love that they have a selection of plant milks for those who are vegan or hate cow's milk (like me!)  

Overall it seems like a great place to chill, read a book, chat with a friend or play a game.  They have Apples to Apples and a group was playing it in the corner.  I love that game!
author: Adrienne J.

description: Nice place to hang out.  Relaxed, plenty of seating.  Liked the decor, and the coffee.
author: Samuel F.

description: I stopped in here for the first time to meet a friend and instantly felt like the ambiance was just a little off. There were homeless people screaming just outside the door, juvenile delinquents smoking pot and people inside were just choosing to ignore it all. That pretty much explains the Haight Ashbury district anyway. I would only recommend for people to come here if they are themselves high. You'll fit right in.
author: Raha G.

description:
One of our first stops during our Haight shopping sprees. GLAD to say that this will be our last visit.  

Stopped in for a treat to fuel our trek on Haight. While scouring the pastry counter, I spotted a winged friend flying from muffin top to muffin top.  

Then, if that was not appauling enough, the barista was getting a pastry for the gentleman in front of me and accidentally knocked a brownie off its pedestal. Im all for not wasting food, but she replaced the brownie with her bear hands.....phalanges wrapped around the tiny dessert. Gross.   

Come on! Germs can be passed by the mishandeling of goods, especially when that person just closed the cash register and had the sniffles. 

We turned around and pushed Coffee to the People to the depths of our minds. They need a lesson on how to be Coffee to the Health and Safety department.
author: April D.

description:
This used to be a go to for me, good coffee and great vegan donuts.   
But you know what? just b/c you serve fair trade coffee doesn't mean you get to shove attitude like THAT is what you are getting paid for,  I have lived in SF for long enough that  I expect to get treated like you are doing me a favor and it is a huge bother to get my drip coffee. 
HOWEVER, the bathroom - Urine all over the place. several pubic hairs on the seat and NO SOAP. Again, I am not a princess. I expect this at a bar. However, one pm on a Friday? NO WAY!
author: kristen l.

description:
My first time in Coffee To The People, I ran in to escape a sudden downpour.  The computerized payment system was down but the barista was mellow and agreeable as were the diverse collection of patrons and their canine friends.  I stayed long after the rain had let up.

This coffee shop's walls are covered with original art and bumper stickers historically found on rainbow vans.  The early morning music soothes and intrigues.  The coffee is quite good as are the baked goods (but they seem a bit on the small size for the price).  I imagine the front window tables would be great for neighborhood people-watching, but I've never gotten here early enough to snag one.
author: Poet D.

description: Organic, sustainable, great strong drip coffee...all the makings of a great neighborhood coffee shop. This one is is large with plenty of seating and obviously well known with its prime location right on Haight & Masonic. Pretty sure I've stopped in everytime I've visited the area!
author: Patrick L.

description:
I took my time to write this review and have visited Coffee to the People several times over the last two months that I have lived here in SF.  My final vote is 3 stars and here's why:

- the coffee is good.  I dare say they make the best vanilla latte in the city, and I say that because they are the only coffee place I know of that can steam rice milk to perfection (I always get my coffees with a dairy alternative).  

- the service is poor.  Now I'm not saying that everybody that works at this place does a bad job.  In fact, I would say that half of the employees are friendly and make your experience pleasant.  However, the other half, other Yelpers have already commented on who those individuals are, offer up the worst coffee bar experience I've ever had.

With that being said, while I will continue to visit CTTP when a vanilla rice milk latte urge kicks, I will always feel like I'm making a gamble.  I can't guarantee on great service every time, which to me is a big deal if I'm going to make a return visit.

Other coffee shops, take note.  Please start offering more than just soy has an alternative to dairy!  Rice milk is so delicious and makes a mean latte.
author: Beenish K.

description:
Originally, I rated a 5 star after my first two encounters.  BUT, after coming back a few times, I've realized that the staff is pretty snobby (even after I tip!). They need to chill out a little bit about being so haight-ashbury trendy.

Besides the staff, I stick to my original review...Great atmosphere--pictures and bumper stickers on the wall.  It felt really cozy and I really enjoyed working on my computer while sipping the AMAZING mint/green tea latte.  

The music they played was also a great mix of familiar and new stuff that I liked.  

Compared to the other 7 coffee shops in the nearby walking radius, I would definitely go here!
author: Abby R.

description:
Great coffee place!  As recent transplants from the 'burbs of Florida, my husband Owen and I found this was the best place to have coffee and free wi-fi access.  Their coffee is great, the couches are comfy and inviting, they have interesting, games, interesting books on socially conscious issues--and most importantly (for me, anyway), their bathroom is CLEAN!!

Plus, they were super-nice: since we were kinda broke and had the added pressure of needing to find an apartment and jobs post-haste, we asked the girl behind the counter (later found out she was one of the owners) if they minded if we were there for a long while using the wi-fi even though we'd only bought 1 coffee each.  She said no problem!  We made the place our official Relocation HQ and went in everyday for our first week in the city.  They didn't disappoint, it was just as nice everytime we went in.  Weekends were considerably more crowded of course, everyone and their mother had their laptop to use the free wi-fi.

I'd agree that they could use a little more selection in their pastries, especially more bagels, please!  But otherwise, very nice place, very sweet people and good comfortable atmosphere; they made a regular out of me!
author: Michelle K.

description:
I walked 6 miles to work this morning.  Partly because I enjoy exercise, and partly because I want to be thinner than my high school classmates at a wedding in a few weeks.

To reward myself halfway through my misty morning treks, I stop in the Haight for coffee.  Kind of as a "you made it from 22nd & Taraval without getting hit by a car.  High 5 for survival" treat.

I choose Coffee to the People because of the people.  Honestly, most coffee tastes the same to me, so it's the service that makes a place stand out.

The coffee is piping hot and worth holding out for, as you'll pass tons of other coffee places on the way.  I slurp my black coffee loudly and efficiently.  I'm a woman on a calorie-burning mission, remember?

The caffeine boost and short respite are just what I need to continue my journey through the Haight and down Market St., finishing at the Embarcadero.

In 3 weeks, I will be perched on the top of a mountain that cuts into the mighty Pacific Ocean, watching two of my old friends exchange handwritten vows in a disgustingly sweet & touching ceremony.  I may or may not vomit over the side of the gazebo.  It will be windy and I will be p*ssed because my hair will be sticking to my pink lipgloss.  The hair in my face will make me look like a Yeti.  But I'll be a svelte Yeti, which is a little sexier.
author: Janney B.

description:
This place has saved my life when I have been ready to die from exhaustion a few times. I drag my ass in, at a crawl. They hand me coffee. I wake up. Hooray!!!!

The name says it all.....this place carries all sorts of vegan stuff, supports eco-friendly businesses and charitable causes. Free WiFi, ample seating (which still manages to fill up to capacity sometimes...be warned) and did I mention they save lives with caffeine? 

I love coffee.
author: Drue C.

description: The Freak Out: 4-Espresso shots in a cup is just I needed for a midday boost.
author: dean d.

description:
Actually, after having experienced the wonder that is Cafe Organica - I have to dock a star for Coffee to the People. Their cafe latte is decent, but it's no Organica. Nevertheless, Coffee to the People does a great job of resurrecting the hippie ideals of Haight from back  when and I don't want to see it going anywhere anytime soon. Plus their sugar cookies are awesome and I've heard good things about the sandwiches. 4/3/06

Coffee to the People is right around the corner from me and when it had first opened, I remember being rather unimpressed with it's inside deco and vibe. All the posters, randomly hung up, seemed to try too hard, and reminded me of Scholastic ordering days back in Elementary school. However, I visited on a whim the other week, and the hype is definitely pretty truthful. It's the people that make this place. There's a very warm atmopshere inside and it's an ideal place to kick back and relax.  Despite all urges to interpret the place as cheesy, I had an awesome time, as I sipped on my chai, watching a variety of musical and poetic performances. All of them - heartfelt and genuine - much like the audience. I felt like I was back at a college open-mike, and reveled in the feeling. I've even been mildly inspired to stop by sometime and share some of my  own writing. (MILDLY) A great addition to Haight Street. There's an abundance of strong postive energy in the place- and when you leave - you feel strangely invigorated.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I'm a coffee snob. Not in the standard 'I only like organic beans' or 'I only drink french roast' or anything... but in a 'Is this made properly?' way. And... at Coffee to the People my latte was perfecto! The fatter the milk, the better the foam, so I'm used to some sub-par foam when I order with 2%. Also the best foam comes from a fresh steam and not a re-heated steam. Despite not being very busy they obviously freshly steam all their milk from a cold pour. My foam was YUMM YUMM! 

I was preparing myself for patchouli and political chants when I walked in and was impressed that despite how hippy it is, it wasn't one of those... 'I'm extremely liberal yet I still feel awkward' places. It was a... 'Yeah... I get it' kinda feeling. They teach you what's compostable, what's recyclable, and have a nice photo of what's landfill. Makes you not want to throw the wrong thing in the wrong place. 

The couches are cozy and the wireless looked exciting. I felt like everyone on their laptop was doing something really good for humanity or writing a really deep poem... then I caught a glimpse of myspace. Oh well. We can always change the world another day.

The only thing I'm not crazy about... yucky bathroom. Piss all over. Someone please come up with a cool green friendly sign that makes the hippies pee IN the toilet and not ON the floor. 
            Like maybe... 
                   Don't be like Bush... Pee in the toilet. 
            or...
                   Urine is sterile, but don't us in peril, Aim for the bowl, it cleanses your soul. 

hmmm... 

Well next time I go, I'll use a clean restroom first and I won't have to bother.
author: Ali R.

description:
I recently spent an entire day working remotely, based out of Coffee to the People, I'm talking easily Dolly Parton hours. The atmosphere is casual, friendly, very much you'd want in a neighborhood coffee spot. 

Being there over the course of the day allowed me to glimpse all variety of folk, if I had been taking photos, the images would have been a nice "coffee" table book, ha ha.

With free wireless, strong and hot coffee, a laid back environment with no pressure to leave... I can now appreciate the name of this place once and for all.
author: Nish N.

description:
CTTP is my favorite coffee shop in the city for a few reasons: the location is convenient for me (Ithe 33 bus is "my line"), the coffee & baristas are excellent, the wi-fi is free (sometimes flaky but still okay), the people are friendly, the book & game library is very compelling. I buy my whole beans here and they're also very good. Fair trade and Organic!

I also love the communal journals floating about. It's fun to write and draw in them, as well as see what others have left behind.

Plus, they have a very excellent website and blog! So very SF.
author: Courtney P.

description:
Coffee to the People is my San Francisco coffeehouse Eden, and here are the three simple reasons why. And they have nothing to do with fair trade, or organic this or that, or political correctness, or the peace-and-love-it-or-Haight-it-vibe (though I have nothing against any of those things)...

1. It's BIG, and it's still COZY/COMFORTABLE.

2. They have AMAZING vegan sandwiches and baked goods (BEYOND the pre-packaged cookies; hello!).

3. FREE WIRELESS!!!

Sometimes I think about moving back to the Haight, just to be closer to C2TP... 

Yeah, I gave it an acronym...
author: Lisa T.

description:
I like CTTP most of all because it's a block from my house. But it's got a pretty good Wi-Fi signal, and you'll most likely find a comfy place to sit, so I'd say it gets about 4 stars. I'm not an authority on coffee, so I can't honestly tell you whether the joe is good or not. It seems alright to me; better than what I make at home at least. 

I found out about Yelp for the first time last summer at CTTP, so it gets 5 stars for that! A little 8x10 Yelp poster haphazardly slapped up on the wall... who woulda known?
author: Chantal H.

description:
When I'm in the Haight I like to stop here for a beverage. This time I ordered tea- Springtime in Paris I believe it was called- black tea with vanilla and lavender and I enjoyed it very much.

Here's a HUGE plus in my book- milk alternatives! They offer soy, almond, rice and hazelnut. Thank you for not just offering soy like every other coffee shop in the world. 

The employees were very nice- no complaints. 
Here is a complaint- flies! There were a lot of bugs flying around and it was kind of gross. There even was one flying in the pastry case. 
While I was looking around I was thinking it seems a little dirty in here. 

The vegan oatmeal cookie I had was real tasty so grab a tea or coffee and a cookie to go unless you enjoy sitting in filth and flies in your face.
author: Katrina B.

description: Nice atmosphere with free wifi. However I will pass on the smoothie. The staff was ok, however, the mango smoothie had bits of plastic all throughout. I'll try to find another coffee shop with free wifi next time.
author: Frank L.

description:
I've been exploring the Haight a lot lately, and it's great because I'm finding a lot of cool places like this one. I came here before actually reading the reviews (gasp!) and I wasn't let down. Their coffee is strong and the pastries are pretty delicious.

The staff was friendly, the dude behind the counter started talking about how my bear claw actually looked like a caterpillar, i was like oh man here we go but the bear claw was pretty incredible.

They have an open mic night for you aspiring musicians, and It appears that they have free WiFi because every table had a laptop on it. Oh, and comfy couches a plenty... yay!

I'll probably be frequenting this place a lot.
author: Richard T.

description:
Best iced mocha I've ever had.

Best tweaked out Barista too.  Who makes the best mocha on ice.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
If you loooove coffee like I loooove coffee, this next sentence may make sense:  After I took my first sip of the hot, dark, flavorful nectar that is the coffee here, I trembled.  

Sorry, Ritual, I've met someone else... And no more long distance relationship, they're right here in the upper Haight.  I've passed them countless times and today, we finally met.  It was Love at first sip.
Less scene more being...But if I find myself in the Mission...

Couldn't tell you foodies about the eats, yet.  But I can tell you this:  Coffee: Out of this world fair trade, organic coffee;  Oasis:  Feels tranquil.  Need to escape from the shopping throngs?   Enter here!  Lots of natural light (i hate fluorescent)  Spacious: sit at the windows and watch the parade or sit further back on inviting couches with friends.   Beautiful, colorful cafe people of all varieties (not wall-to-wall lap-toppers, thankfully.), deRiguer WiFi, friendly staff, interesting and eclectic and ...did I mention the coffee?
L.
author: Grrrl W.

description:
I liked this place because it's big and organized.  I've been to a lot of college coffee shops and they're pretty good, but this place has the left-wing slogans on one wall, then the famous leader quotations on another, and the couches with the books in a whole other section, so no matter where you end up sitting you get a pretty good experience.

They also had free wi-fi when I needed to find out where the hell I was, which happens pretty often.  Places that help me find my bearings when I am lost hold a special place for me.  I will come here again.
author: Cassio P.

description:
I grew up on truck stop coffee.

Now that I'm old and tough, 
yet fancy,
I'm all about Fraunch presses.

Their knowledgeable staff stuffs my press pot* with choice selections from a wide variety of excellent organic coffees and they insist on serving it with a pitcher of cream and a bowl of sugar, though I can't understand why anyone would want to dilute this chalky nectar.

Hooray!

*that sounds kinda dirty. heheheh.
author: Don Q.

description: This is my neighborhood coffee shop. It's a great place to grab a cup and get some work done at a less busy time. Good coffee, free wifi, casual atmosphere. Having to deal with a few street kids/trust fund hippies is just the nature of living in the haight. You just have to know how to tune things out. In short, I really dig this place.
author: Scott A.

description:
I'm a CTTP regular.  Their coffee is decent, usually, and consistently strong.  The food is better than average for a coffeehouse though the selection is limited.  The soups are particularly good (especially the Thai Peanut) and the portions are generous.  The sandwiches are huge (and difficult to bite into because of their height) and filled with fresh ingredients.  Love all the vegan options like the vegan doughnuts.  I love toasted bagels with Tofutti.  The bagel guy doesn't get there till around 7:30 AM though.

What really makes this place special is its community - it attracts a truly diverse group of people including some colorful regulars, not all of whom have homes.  It also attracts professionals, tourists, artist types, etc.  The staff is very laid back.  They support local artists and give back to the community.  They're good about recycling too.  They display the work of local artists on the walls.  It's hard not to like a place like this.  Oh and sometimes they play music I really like (e.g., Cure, She Wants Revenge) too.  Sometimes they play music I really can't stand too, but oh well.

It's a cozy & comfortable place to plug in your laptop (plenty of power outlets) and sit.  They have a bathroom too.  And games.  And books.  Open mic night on Tuesdays.  Credit cards accepted, $5 minimum.  They have a frequent buyer card for the coffee drinks too.

Tip:  Some of the customers have body odor, so try to sit near the door.

Update:  They stopped making sandwiches long ago.  I'm sad to hear that the new owners took away the health care benefits the employees had.  I read about it in the Haight Ashbury Beat.  So far the menu is the same.  The bathroom used to be open to the public but people started using the sink to wash themselves (ha ha), so now it's for customers only.
author: Lolia S.

description:
As trendy and cliche hippieish this place may be, i enjoyed it. I am all for the eco friendliness and animal rights awareness, etc. So i totally support that aspect.
After a long exhausting day of walking around, my boyfriend and i were meeting up with 2 of our friends in 30 minutes and had some time to kill, so we thought, why not get coffee again, for the 3rd time that day. So we wandered over here because i remembered reading about this place and it looked really cute/the least sketchy in the area. 
I got ... you guessed it...an iced mocha. with soy, of course. As i always do. they use the same soy that Coffee Bean does, which i was glad to see because it's one of my favorites. It was pretttty good, could have been a little stronger for my taste, but it was late and i already had a shitload of espresso for the day, i figured it was a good thing to take a small break. the homemade whipped cream was delicious though, i asked for a refill on it. Except the girl who i asked was kind of rude and of course rolled her eyes when i asked for some more. Maybe this place should start promoting friendly service along with everything else they stand for.

the one other thing that bothered me were all of the trendy kids hanging out here pretending to be vegan haha. Kind of funny though. How pathetic. Only on Haighttt haha.
But i do suggest it. It's a good place to come, relax, read the paper and get a drink. they also have a variety of vegan drinks. Nice.
author: Amanda S.

description: While everyone is in a hurry to get a coffee or food on haight st, and over pay for it, this little place is just as good as any of those other places. Good coffee, good bfest sandwiches, and pastries. They take cards which i love and offer wifi.
author: Raul R.

description: This is my favorite new(ish) coffee shop. It's got great brewed coffee. It's in my part of town. Some comfy couches, and it's not a chain. The kids behind the counter are pretty cool. Give this place a try - the Haight needs this place!!!
author: Dale D.

description:
If you needed two reasons I think worth going to this place: mint matcha mocha and their Veggie Delight sandwich.  :)

They have strong free WiFi, lots of tables, a couple comfy sofas in the back, board games, and just a generally welcoming atmosphere.  I've had excellent service and the prices seem reasonable.  They are also trying to do "game nights" once a month---come on down and play games with your neighbors and locals!

They do seem to be "commuter friendly" if you feel the need to get some work done from there.

The only negative I had was a bum coming up to me and demanding part of my sandwich.  Oh well, I guess that's what you get being near Haight and Masonic.  :P

Times visited: 10+
author: Amy L.

description: Bad coffee + stinks like urine don't go here - walk down to divisadero or go to cole valley cafe.
author: Ben B.

description:
(edit: they open their bathrooms to ANYONE, not just paying customers, and it still looks FAN Freaking TASTIC!) 

Games to play (wide variety), good coffee (used to work in a coffee shop so I know), great customer service! I sit for 3 hours each weekend doing work and it never seems to be a problem (when I worked in a coffee shop we would be rude to the people who overstayed there small cup of coffee sized welcome, oh the irony!) Good food for breakfast or snack, and great sized tables, perfect for studying/doing work - and of course, free wifi!
author: Christina G.

description:
I am a coffee fan.  I am a fan of vegan options.  I am a fan of sustainable agriculture.  However, I am not a fan of  rudeness and inefficiency.   A compassionate business person needs to have a sustainable business plan (services that contribute to greater good, please customers and produce a healthy profit) so that you can pay your help and your bills.  I get it, you have to show how socialist you are by spending ten minutes helping the clueless woman who doesn't know what a cappucino or a scone is.  Explain to her the nuances if you must, but at least get some other drinks started.  

The coffee was so-so, the help was slow and indifferent, at least toward people who work for a living.  I do not care how concerned one is about  environment, etc, when a person enters a coffee place during the commuting hours, one does not appreciate snail service with a frown.  Check it out:  it takes a reasonable income to pay $7 for coffee and a pastry on a routine basis, so you'd better value this customer, too.  I'm a deserving customer even though I wear nice shoes and comb my hair.  You would be suprised to know how much of my energy and resources go to greater good issues.

The place isn't clean enough.  Hippies can be clean.  There is no law that says a hippie business has to be gritty and dirty.  Clean your store or rename it "Coffee for the Dirty People"  Yep, I'm talking to you.  The napkin, milk, sugar, condiment station was a dirty wreck.  Perhaps this was anomaly, nonetheless, this was my first and last visit.  I want good coffee and non-surley service for my $4 coffee, $pastry payment.
author: michaelangela v.

description:
Pretty cool place if you're down to get your preppy on and drink some pretty good coffee.

The decor is rather contrived, but completely within their marketing mission... it's all "Dude, the people are coolies." and when you're reading it, you're like... "Dude! YEAH! That's like totally what I was just thinking!" Then you order your super feel good, super expensive (for coffee) "Chocolate to the People"(tm) and you're like whoa... I'm totally patting myself on the back for drinking something so fairly traded!

(They totally TM'ed the name Chocolate to the People too, super cool!)

The drink rocked though, chocolate and espresso.... oh yeah. The place is pretty clean as well, and even has spent coffee grounds (to pick up, I think) for composting.

I'll be back, probably often, and I'm so taking pictures of their roadmap to fascism. I mean, I need something to do in my spare time...
author: Dave M.

description:
OMfuckingG i love CTTP. i was a straight black coffee kinda girl for years, but CTTP has gently pulled me back to my freshman-year-college-vanilla-latte roots. well, kind of. 

i'm always suckered in by that festive sign they have outside, imploring me to try their creation of the day. rasberry mocha with little candies floating in it? sold! minty hot chocolate that doesn't even contain coffee? why not??? if you're not suuuuper hungry, CTTP is a nice place to go for a leisurely breakfast. they don't have a huge menu, but there are a few normal egg type dishes offered, as well as bagels (tofutti cream cheese is available). they've also got a wide selection of pastries, both vegan and non-vegan. i probably shouldn't be posting this on yelp as the stock is already limited and i get super angry and sad when they're sold out, but the vegan chocolate turnovers are sooo good. ask them to microwave it for a couple of seconds and it gets gooey and even more delicious!

the only slight problem i have with CTTP is that i never know how to act toward the counter staff. should i return the surly attitude so that they think i'm cool? or should i just go for it and try to be friendly on the off chance that they'll reciprocate? oh, who am i kidding, they'll never reciprocate. i think the last time i went in there i was clad in a head-to-toe uc hastings sweatsuit. i may as well have been wearing a sign that said "Nerd (but not in the cute, kitschy way)."

sigh. at least i know that no matter how lame i realize i am when i set foot in CTTP, i can always drown my sorrows in a delicious coffee (or non-coffee) beverage. WITH vegan whipped cream, thank you very much.
author: Jessica C.

description: I tried the matcha mint mocha! it was def a solid buy b/c even though it was a bit pricey, it was a big size and it def warmed me up! the cafe is really spacious and there were a lot of ppl surfing the web. I would def love to come back here again and chillax.
author: Yumi H.

description:
I've got Mondays off now. It's true. I got a new job & they put me on a Tuesday thru Saturday schedule. So last Monday I got on my bike, rode up to Haight & camped out at coffee to the people, where I sat in quiet solitude & read the paper. Yes, I sat there for over an hour & my phone didn't ring & I didn't speak & I didn't move. It was amazing.

This is the most distinguishably Socialist-run business in a very distinguishably Socialist neighborhood. Or maybe they're Commies? Eh, either way, they make a mean bagel w/cream cheese & avocado, & all the coffee is high quality free trade, etc. I'm also impressed that they had a compost bin next to the standard recycle bin & trash bin.

A little on the expensive side, but they pride themselves on fair business practices & high-quality products, so I won't complain about that.
author: Pete J.

description: Meh, the vegan food looked good but the coffee blew. Different staff, same look, different vibe.
author: Mark B.

description: Good coffee and great chai (more spicy, less sweet). Free wifi and plenty of seating   (including a mix of sofa space and table space) are also pluses. The atmosphere is a bit dark and dingy though.
author: Chris T.

description:
Yay to a local coffee/cafe spot in my 'hood.

Milk variety - like almond or rice milk when I'm feeling a little too "normal" with my latte

Board games! + lots of coffee = :)

A warm feeling that makes you happy to be a local. And what can beat a "warm feeling?"

Nay to Stabucks, Yay to Coffee to the People!
author: Deann M.

description:
The ingredients are pretty simple: lots of comfortable furniture, a full coffee/tea menu, pastries and bistro snacks, and wireless internet. It's surprising the Haight doesn't have more places like this. Cole Valley Cafe is close but doesn't have much space or comfort, and La Boulange doesn't have wifi.
