So I appreciate Coffee To The People for filling a need, and really doing it quite well. The coffee menu's inventive and complete, the service is friendly, and they serve good non-pastry options like sandwiches and lasagna. The coffee's generally fine and you can indulge in hazelnut milk.

This five star rating is according to a certain taste: the furniture is threadbare, the plates and glasses chipped and random. Earnest political posters and bumper stickers on the walls give lip service to the neighborhood theme. You wouldn't take anyone here to impress them, but it's a great place to feel perfectly at ease. 

Sure there are negatives. The soymilk is only vanilla, despite the presence of vanilla syrup someone could ask for if they wanted that. It's not the pitch-perfect coffee you'd get at Philz or Ritual. And they can't help that the occasional unbathed Haight denizen with the shakes will plop himself next to you. Should I withhold a star? Nah -- Coffee To The People delivers the homey, threadbare coffeehouse experience, and doesn't pretend to be anything else.
author: Rainbucket B.

description:
2 stars - Fast, reliable, and free wi-fi connection.  Since Canvas cafe in the Inner sunset is closing, this is going to be my new go-to place on my work-from-home days.

1 star - Good organic, fair trade coffee.

1 star - Delicious chocolate chip cookie.

1 star - Clean bathroom.
author: Chris Q.

description:
This is an old-school type of cafe you would have found in S.F. or Berkeley BITD: good coffee, Italian sodas, yummy munchies, painted and bumper-stickered walls--a cool little hangout. 

Forty years after the Summer of Love sitting there tonight listening to a guitarist playing who sounded like Mr. Dylan I closed my eyes and was almost briefly transported to that magical '60s time and place older people talk about having been so awesome.

Check out the very friendly open mic here every Tuesday night  hosted by ultracool musician Dogman Joe.
author: Nivek M.

description:
Oct 2013
New management. Cleaned up quite a bit. Far less street folks but still some.


2011
Completely taken over by  the street transients.  
The side walk has moved inside with dogs sleeping on the floor, people sleeping on the couches.  The staff and management I guess don't care. But if you need buy drugs, this is the place.
author: MILTON V.

description: I love this coffee shop and I truly wish there was one like it in San Diego. Plenty of seating to lounge and hangout while your enjoying your coffee. While I was waiting for my drink I really liked looking at the decor which consist of bumper stickers.  I ordered the ice mocha which was pretty darn good. Next time I'm in town I'll have to try their vegan donuts for sure.
author: Emy R.

description:
I've been going to Coffee to the People for a while now...let's see, I guess it's going on our 11-month anniversary.  At first our relationship was a little tenuous.  The coffee was good...and I loved the hippie vibe.  But it wasn't enough for me.  I wanted more...

Okay, seriously though.  It's taken me a while to fall in love with Coffee to the People.  I go in a lot.  I'd say, on average at least 3 times a week.  Let's talk about the coffee first.  I'm a fan.  It's never been burnt, it's always good and hot.  Other drinks are solid too...although sometimes the matcha lattes are a little heavy on the matcha.  Oh, and you can get a nice big pot of tea for pretty cheap.

Now let's talk about the people.  A number of other Yelp reviews have called out the fact that some of the employees aren't what you might call chatty cathys.  And I must admit, it took a while for some of the employees to warm up, despite my frequent visits.  At first I was a little shy.  But then one day, I decided to buck up and make the first move.  

That's right...I asked the baristas how they were doing....every day.  At this point, I know most all of the morning folk by name, and I definitely chat it up with Ashley, Mary, Jenina (although I don't know how to spell her name), Austin, Laura, and Fernando.  Not all mornings are created equal.  And I certainly can understand not feeling super chatty when you're exhausted....but at this point, I know and like them all so we don't always have to talk (yes, we've gotten to that point in the relationship).

And as far as the atmosphere, it's so very Haight, from the wall of stickers, to the anti-war tables, to the rotating art exhibits.  There's always something (or someone) to look at.  The wi-fi is solid too, and even when I was using Coffee to the People as my office-away-from-the-office and sitting there on my laptop for 6 to 8 hours at a time, they never batted an eye.

At the end of the day, I love this place.  And sure, it took some work.  But I think it's worth it.
author: Cristina F.

description:
when I work in a cafe, I need 3 things: coffee, bagels, and wifi. coffee to the people delivers hands down on coffee, meh on bagels, and blech on wifi. If they had consistent wifi I would go all the time but its very low if you can even get a connection.

I still pass and grab some joe though - the lattes make me so happy!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I'm a hot chocolate girl at heart.  Try as I might to doctor coffee with soymilk-and-Splenda alchemy, even the best caffe latte never tastes quite as good to me as a mug of thick, dark chocolate.  I do, however, get occasional cravings for mochas, and Coffee to the People makes the finest in town.

It's not just the exquisite mochas--which can be made sugar-free if you like, and boast a high enough chocolate-to-coffe ratio to keep this cacao lover very happy--that keep me coming back.  The space is airy, lazy, and always brimming with positivity.  Old couches invite you to stay and read awhile, and high windows allow sunshine to filter in and warm the whole room.  The baristas have all gratuated from Hipster Modeling School: their look is edgy, dark, and hot hot HOT.  Even better, they treat customers with nothing but the utmost friendliness and patience; I've never encountered so much as a shred of attitude here.

Coffee to the People is so good, it almost makes me want to switch beans.  Almost.
author: Karin H.

description:
I like this place, but don't know its really a place I'd go to spend an afternoon.

 Usually I just run in for some coffee, get some help from the AWESOME and lovely staff and head on out.

But the other day my friend got some vegan blended drink with cookies and "creme"... OH MY GOD.... I couldn't believe what I was tasting was vegan... it was next to godliness.

Cheers to them for offering TONS of vegan delights, and fair trade coffees.
author: Roachie D.

description:
What to add to all the other reviews? 

The only thing you need to know is that you can get a fourth shot in a large if you so choose. 

And choose you should.
author: The Sock S.

description:
This coffee shop just narrowly missed getting 2 stars.

Sunday evening... around 7, the place was almost empty and ordered an americano. Certainly not a labor intensive drink. However, at some point my order got dropped and I was totally forgotten about. I bellied up to the counter about 10 minutes later and gave the barista sad puppy dog eyes and a little hint that I was thirsty.

She apologized profusely and quickly made my drink. In additional to the apologies I got a free drink coupon. I was quite pleased! I understand screwing up from time to time, but a shop that will actually go out of their way to make up for it awesome in my book.

Oh, and the americano was descent. No complaints. Atmosphere was pretty comfortable as well. Lots of space and well lit for studying (which seemed to be a popular activity).
author: Rhett G.

description:
Got yelled at by a barista because i did not properly recycle my coffee cup in each of the three separate bins.   

Decent coffee, spare the attitude.
author: Alex J.

description:
So, what can I say that hasn't already been said?  Despite this coffee shop requiring me to walk down and back up the "Ashbury Hill of Calf Muscle Destruction"(TM), I happily do it once a week for my weekend coffee trip.  The coffee itself is quite tasty and I love the pastries.  While I am not Vegan, the vegan pastries have ended up on my plate on occassion.  

This morning I brought my laptop in to take advantage of the free wifi and realized I was a minority.  Oh there were plenty of laptops, but god forbid you don't own a Mac as you will look like a total outsider :)
author: Jeff R.

description:
Great looking place!

I know this place opened quite a while back, but for some reason I never tried it.

Today, things have changed, I did try it, and here is what I liked:
 - large room
 - couches
 - free internet connection
 - laid back atmosphere

that's all I am looking for in a coffee shop. Haven't tried their food though. Next time. Coffee a little expensive (2,50 for a large coffee) but ok for the comfort you get in return :)
author: xavier v.

description:
You certainly powered my flower!

Let me start off by saying that this is my first review on Yelp. I've used Yelp often since I moved to Berkeley, but never have I delved into the area of writing on the site. That being said, I am hesitant to give my first review such a rave review - I wouldn't want anyone to think I'm just giving stars away for the sake of star-giving power. On the contrary, I felt so compelled to sit down and write this review because Coffee to the People was in fact so worthy! In sum, I'm not a star whore - CTTP (as it is lovingly referred to by others) is truly worth my rating!

And now for why CTTP has earned five stars in my book...

A little background: I got to Haight a little later than I had planned, was starving, irritable and a little discombobulated in general. Life seemed all-too-overwhelming and my wandering that day felt particularly aimless. All I wanted was a good old fashioned cup of black gold. I stumbled into CTTP and at first glance thought, "Oh great, another place where the staff and clientele alike are going to stick up their noses at my designer sunglasses and scoff at how I don't belong." 

But to my delight, no one seemed to care either way. I wasn't paid much attention to, but I also wasn't brushed off or treated rudely. Essentially, I was left to be, which was just what I was looking for. 

My first instinct was to order a very large black coffee...that is until I spotted the Flower Power - a vegan drink of espresso, chai and soymilk. $5 for a cup of coffee you ask? Oh yes, and worth every penny. My drink was fixed quickly and even had a little flower drawn on the cup. I'm generally not a sucker for cutesy nothings but in that moment it put a smile on my face, and that's worth noting! The drink itself warmed my heart, my belly, and satisfied my taste buds. Only problem is, I think I'm spoiled for life!

There was also a nice collection of vegan snacks which all looked excellent - I settled on a cookie, which the barista was happy to warm up for me - and the sandwiches that they offered seemed appetizing. 

Unfortunately, all of the couches and armchairs were occupied, but I settled for a cozy nook, which wasn't so bad because the  the chairs and benches had pillows aplently to sit on, lean on or even hide yourself away in. 

My nook was situated next to a bulletin board dedicated to bumper stickers, which kept me occupied for some time! I also brought along with me to my nook Trivial Pursuit. CTTP has a vast collection of games to choose from, and being a nerd, I love flipping through Trivial Pursuit cards learning useless yet ever so enticing tidbits. Their game collection was a definite plus!

Admittedly, I did not use the bathroom, which I often use as an indicator of a restaurant/cafe/anywhere that should have a toilet's overall cleanliness and customer service. Regardless, with Flower Power, vegan treats, games aplenty and free internet access, to boot, Coffee to the People is a treasure, in my opinion!

I left feeling refreshed, caffeinated and totally empowered. To quote Schwarzie: "I'll be back!"
author: Erica M.

description: Okay, my motivation for going here wasn't to use the free wi-fi or to soak up some mellow vibes...this is where the Haunted Haight tour begins. I ordered a large ice-tea for $2.75 and settled at one of the vacant tables to wait for the tour guide. A few people sat around with their laptops, oblivious to the guy who was trying to sell a bag of five joints for $10 just outside the door. The pastry selection looked real good at it IS pretty laid back, even for Haight Street. My guide showed up so I didn't get a chance to have anything but the tea..
author: michael s.

description:
Alright, so  I guess I am going to have to go against the grain here.  I went to check out this coffee shop mostly because I love coffee shops and this one had been rated so damn highly by every one on yelp.  I thought that the space reminded me of my home room from 7th grade and I didn't think it was very cozy or comfortable or nice. My mocha was ok but nothing amazing.  

I didn't use the free wifi...that may have changed my rating.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I have tried to like this place. It is true that they have free wi-fi and lots of comfortable seating, which is a plus. However, their coffee is very mediocre and over priced. It is the most expensive coffee shop of this caliber that I know of in SF. 

The kicker for me, and what motivated me to write this review, was the fact that I ordered two bagels with cream cheese, I walked home, gave one to my girlfriend and proceeded to eat mine. Both of us tasted the undeniable taste of cigarettes on the bagels, as if the guy who made them had just chain smoked and not washed his hands. Gross! This was on top of a lot of smug attitude employees gave me for no reason. I have worked customer service jobs for most of my working life and I know that it sucks so I am always polite and tip well to service workers, so I don't feel like I deserve it. I know they have lip rings and all, but they don't need to take that out on me. 

Blah.
author: Robin H.

description:
First, props for having something clearly vegan on the menu.

I ordered the vegan sandwich - olive spread, hummus, tomatoes, cucumbers.  One major requirement of something being a sandwich is the ability to pick it up and take a bite out of it.

The sandwich was so tall no one would be able to take a bite out of it. Why do people do this? I had to squish it to have some sort of corner to chomp on. It started falling apart on my first bite. I somehow was able to slurp through the first half. The second half I literally has to pick apart and eat with my fork.
author: Janet B.

description: Although I haven't yet tried the coffee (just the lemonade iced tea) I think this place is tops. Me and some friends came here and sprawled out on the couches with books for a few hours. No one bothered us, the atmosphere was pleasant (as were the other patrons) and we even got in a few rounds of Scattergories.
author: Natalye R.

description:
It's my local haunt for sure.  They serve fair trade coffee and tasty breakfast treats.  They even cater to the vegan folks out there.  CTTP is now serving odd looking vegan donuts which I've yet to try.  

Give their white hot chocolate a try!  Yum!
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Good job on the basics (coffee and pastries are decent if not very unique, staff is friendly), but stands out on the extras.

The free WiFi works well, seating (couches and tables/chairs) is plentiful, and they've thoughtfully placed lots of power outlets around. There's a little library and set of board games. And they donate some percent of their profits to progressive causes.
author: Rick C.

description:
My favorite coffee place on Haight!

It's fun to hang out here since there's lots of space, 5 or 6 couches and lots of board games and books to borrow... lending a community atmosphere.

Austin is totes cute, and makes great drinks.

Speaking of drinks, they have a great selection of offerings--from creative tea and flavored espresso 'ochas and 'ottos to your basic coffee (in medium or dark roast, take your pick).

I'm not vegan or gluten allergic but I can appreciate that CTTP has a wide selection as well for my diet-restricted friends--even if they're only imaginary friends.

Closing thoughts: bumpersticker wall!  For hippies without cars (yay)!
author: Peter v.

description:
I like this place a lot! 

The coffee selection is delicious, especially for those of us that like to drink quality mud!

Try their coffee cake, i thoroughly enjoyed it, though at the time was inspired by the Haight lifestyle;) 

This one time, my buddy Brett Hunter and I went there to jam a bit, me on upright and him on acoustic guitar, totally chill Cat Stevens styley. they said no, so that is why they are not 5 stars. 

i think they will let us jam there soon though, as they said just give them more of a heads up. but to me, isn't an independent coffee shop supposed to be open to spontaneity? especially if they are called Coffee to the People.

they still get my business.

for all of you tourists reading this, if you're on Haight, it is a crime not to go into Amoeba Records at least once to see what a real record store is like. 

peace!
tony


www.almadmusic.com
author: Tony G.

description:
Just had one quick afternoon off in SF, headed to Haight st looking for a nice coffee shop and there it was, On Masonic at Haight. I didn't hang out there too long but i can tell you that their Mocha is absolutely delicious. 
If i lived there it would probably be one of my neighborhood's favorite.
Delicious fair trade coffee.
author: Celine N.

description: Coffee to the people has a lot of grouchy baristas who are too young to have lived in the sixties but seem to base their lives on it.  the coffee was decent but they tried to make me feel like a jerk for getting coffee a half hour before they were closing.  5 minutes might be pushing it, but brewed coffee with a half hour to go... isn't that inconvenient.
author: James L.

description:
My usual is a vanilla or white choco latte, but most places somehow make a poor version of it.  The vanilla syrup is usually stuck in the very bottom and by the time you're done with your cup, you have this last shot of concentrated sweetness down you're throat.  Gah...

But CTTP knows how to mix it throughout.  Yum!  I like that they have caffeine specials, concoctions made specifically by the cafe.  Worth a taste, but the price for a cup goes pass $4.  They serve food here, savory or sweet, hot or cold.

If you're lucky snag a table, but I'm sure the regulars totally hoard their spot early on.  Every table has a white Macbook and the patrons are totally tuned out to their hippie oversized headphones.  And they get to stay there for 1/2 the day because they still have about a sip and a half left on their $2 tea.  

Toward the back there are a few big cushy couches with plenty of books and even board games to borrow.  Man, this place really encourages you to basically bum it here for hours on end.  I hope they charge rent to some... well, their semi-pricey coffee probably acts as just that.
author: Chris T.

description:
Went here for the cider because I was frigging FREEZING. The cider was ok, I'd rather pay the extra $$$ to get some caramel, whipped cream, and chattery at the ol' bucks. My bf got a hot chocolate which wasn't anything special either. 

The workers were indifferent to my patronage. I figure as a visitor, I wouldn't mind, but didn't seem like they cared to establish any colloquial relationship with the other customer's there. Hence, why I'd rather go to the ol' bucks and pay that extra money for some friendship and good laughs. Back to harbor and adams!
author: Alex T.

description:
Per the SF Chronicle, I am a neo-nomad, a bedouin of San Francisco, and I'm proud of it!

Like other neo-nomads, I seem to find myself here at Coffee to the Peeps (as I call it) on a semi-regular basis.  Why?
* Friendly Staff
* Sweet + Savory snacks 
* Tables + Couches + Armchairs (sometimes it's nice to have variety in where you are working)
* Good Coffee
* Fast free wi-fi

This is a great office-away-from-home....
author: Jane A.

description:
No, not a favorite.  Tried laptopping it here and didn't enjoy the environment which was a bit too bustling for me. 

More so, though, I wasn't  too fond of some of the staff.  Maybe they get harried too often there since it's in the Haight?  But I felt it was such a imposition on them to request a container for my sandwich leftovers.  That and they actually eave the front unmanned at times so some people were just standing there waiting to be served.  Kinda funky when there are a slew of people behind the counter frittering with various things.  Um?

I also couldn't manage to snatch one of the myriad of tables - it was a full house, so I got one of the cushy chairs near the service counter.

I liked my sandwich and the matcha latte I had, but I don't think I'll be coming back to knock off some work again.
author: Femita J.

description:
The coffee isn't anything great though I like that its fair trade and their snacks and treats are vegan friendly. A few good originals on the menu like their mocha with a hint of orange given the cliche name of "Golden Gate" though still quite tasty, a nice atmosphere with accessible wi-fi and a generally friendly staff. 

Their bathroom could definitely use a new everything, I've been to some fairly remote places in the world and for a simple coffee shop in San Francisco this place's restroom is up there fighting for the most disgusting. 

The could also use a wider variety of teas, especially iced, overall though definitely a place worth a try, always good for a pick me up while shopping on Haight St. and makes for interesting people watching at any time of the day.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
I really want to like this place. They've got decent fair trade coffee and a broad selection of tea. It's also a lot cleaner and safer than, say, Rockin' Java up the street.

The reason I give this place 3 stars is because the employees here are just so GD spacey. I mean out to lunch. I've asked for things in the past like a refill of hot water for my tea, for example, only to have the girl walk around looking confused, disappear to the back, and then come out and help someone else. If the canister of soy milk is empty, forget asking to get that replaced. Not gonna happen.

Today, though, was an exception. I telecommute most Fridays and rely a lot on the Internet to get work done. When it went out, unexpectedly, I leaned over and asked another patron with a laptop if she was having the same problem? Yes. So, I asked her to watch mine while I approached the counter to inform the staff. What did I get? "The router is right behind you. YOU can go unplug it and plug it back in after a minute." Well, thank you for ordering me, the customer, around. I really appreciate the consideration. Next time, ASK if I wouldn't mind since there were three of you behind the counter helping ONE other customer.

And that concludes my review. I think I'll stick to Coffee Bar or Sugarlump where the staff is a bit friendlier.
author: Kara M.

description:
I was first confused because there's this People's Cafe just around the corner but my friend insisted No, this was the place we had to try. 
Confusing I think but I wasn't confused about my beverage.
This was probably the Best Soy Hot Chocolate I have had in a long, long time.  I don't know what they do and I probably don't want to know but they got it right. 
They seemed nice enough but we're really the quickest baristas outside of Starbucks to be sure.
My friend, eager for the trip there, looked pained.  Something wasn't right, not even close.  She got this macha concotion and well, I'll be on my own in the future.  
And I'll get it to go. A lot going on in this cafe and not sure I think the space, and there's much if it, is laid out to its potential. On this particular visit it was nasty outside and I needed a cozy cafe.  
This wasn't that.
author: Sean S.

description: Used to be my go-to coffee place in the neighborhood. It's not anymore. Since it changed ownership, the coffee has gotten to be simply TERRIBLE. The last 3 lattes I've had have been burned and disgusting. The loyalty program is no longer, and it's not even worth a stop in anymore. I get my coffee elsewhere- Haight Street Market is now serving Blue Bottle, just a few blocks away with a loyalty program, awesome coffee and without the 'tude.
author: Emily M.

description:
I was in the neighborhood in search of a good cafe, peeked into Coffee to the People...hmm alot of young people on their laptops and good lighting. Looks like one of the only promising options for some good reading space amid the sea of shops and bars down Haight.

When my friend placed our orders, they forgot to make my ice coffee. We asked for it again and the guy at the counter made a HOT coffee instead. After realizing his mistake, he said just said "oops" but gave no apologies. As much as I wanted to give this place a chance, it didn't help that the coffee had a taste of funk in it. I even taste checked the half and half in case it was a case of bad milk...nope it's just a case of bad coffee. And the gritty couches just made it that much harder to stay very long.

By the way, the people who take their shoes off and prop their dirty socks on the coffee tables here...keep 'em on! No one needs to be subjected to dirty feet on the table meant for food.
author: Mary H.

description:
You need to be a regular to come here.  But how you become a regular without starting as a newbie, that makes my head spin.

I waited in a short line where it seemed like everyone said "the usual" and got whatever it was they wanted.  I was tempted to do so to see what I'd end up with.

Okay, not really.  But going here did, in some ways, feel like I was in a foreign country.  Different ambiance, different language.  My eyes barely finished reading the menu before I was at the barista.  "Um, medium mocha?"

And it was good.  That might be my usual from now on.  If I ever make it out again, that is.

[So why 3 stars?  The discomfort of being in a foreign environment.  Redeeming quality was a good couch area for lounging.  And hiding.]
author: Athena ..

description:
Coffee, WiFi, vegan.
Okay, about the coffee: great foam on the vegan lattee's (something that I never thought possible on soymilk).  Plus: Fair trade coffee (I think all of it is).
About the free WiFi: didn't work once out of five times... kindof a bummer when you make this a destination spot (meaning, for the free wifi).  But the other times worked perfectly.  Maybe it was the full moon... or the spy station nearby.
Vegan: meaning a good amount available.  I will update this when I actually move back here and eat something.  Nonetheless, kudos for carrying stuff.

Minus the point for: the WiFi that wasn't that time (yes, I know, only Al Gore controls the internet); and the overly sketchy people that are occasionally there and made me change my seat cause the smell was overpowering (again, one of five times, so another half point off).

Overall,
Thank you for being the Haight/Ashbury cafe that I will come back to again and again.  You've restored my faith in people.
author: Pratik P.

description:
I throughly love this coffee shop! They make good drinks. The service is good. It is a good place to come to study and/or chill with friends. They also have a ton of books that you can read while there.

p.s check out their wall of AWESOME bumper stickers.
author: Simmy S.

description:
Overheard while on line to order: 
"It is just more spiritual to live in a world of spirits"

If you can stomach that - or, like me, relish the self-indulgent and unfair judgment of strangers - this place has pretty good coffee and free WiFi. 

Not too quiet though, so not so great if you need to get important work done.
author: John E B.

description:
This place is right around the corner from where I work, and I adore them. The atmosphere is awesome. They've got good quality coffee. The autumn harvest tea is my favorite! 
How could you smack talk a coffee shop with board games, cool staff, and great products. I'm not vegan, but I appreciate how far they go to accommodate that population. And it's the meeting place for the Haunted Haight tours.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Nice coffee shop.  The coffee is really good, the location is spacious, and the baristas are sweet.  Also they have an easily assessable free wireless network (no signing up on a website required).  

While I was sitting around drinking my coffee one of the guys working there walked around giving everyone shot size glasses of tea to taste.
author: Katie S.

description:
I can agree with most of the recent reviewers. The coffee is not outstanding, the aimless wanderers that deposits themselves on the corners of this neighborhood, and the sometimes annoying music selection are definite deterrents. 

But on the flip side, the Wi-Fi is free and it works, there is always somewhere to sit and it's usually comfortable, and most importantly 75% of the time there is at least one cute young girl working behind the counter and 98% of the time they're pleasant with everyone. Including this very moment.
author: Jason R.

description: Alright, I'll admit it.  This has been my go-to spot when I'm job hunting.  They have a great atmosphere and none of the employees make you feel like you're not welcome here.  The drinks and food are wonderful, as well!  Yeah, there are a few bums hanging around outside, but you know what? This is the Haight - get used to it!
author: Janell F.

description:
Great music. Cool crowd. Best random conversations. Free wi-fi. 

The coffee was delicious. I can't remember which one I had, but I had it black and it was tasty. Not acidic, not too strong. Would definately go back.
author: Sue Y.

description: If Kerouac and Ginsberg were to come back as ghosts, this is where they would go for coffee and some amazing pastries.  The pumpkin flavored chai is insane.
author: Andrew K.

description:
The first time I came in here, I got a latte, started working on my laptop, but then put it down, and read Aaron McGruder and Kyle Baker's "Birth of a Nation" graphic novel for about half an hour.  Pretty subversive stuff, if you know what I'm talking about.  And that about sums up the place-- you know you can just get the single latte, but there's more under the surface.

Now that I live three blocks away, I usually get their strong coffee to go, as I have my wireless and comfy chair at home.  But whenever I've worked there, getting some sunlight and seeing other fresh faces, I've never felt "wi-fired."  And that says a lot.  It's a brave move to allow pale white guys with PowerBooks and giant headphones to bogart valuable seating space during normal business hours.  We're not exactly the most glamorous, friendly pack in the world.

But there's where the social justice theme kicks in.  Free wi-fi isn't free, after all.  So CttP is the only place where I feel a societal obligation to reup on baked goods if I'm sticking around.  Its walls whisper, 'do the right thing.'

Then I'll go home and turn on all the lights.  But, hey, every little bit, you know?
author: Jeff M.

description:
They have a respectable selection of drinks and things to nibble on, I had an iced coffee and a tamale pie, and both were good.

I happened to catch the place on a nice day and it was beautiful sitting near the front of the shop looking out the windows. 

Sure, there were definitely vagrants around, but welcome to the neighborhood. No one was causing trouble or being obnoxious, and certainly anyone can do that, regardless of socioeconomic standing. 

Overall, the place is a solid coffee shop and I'm looking forward to coming back. I just wish they were open to 9 or 10 during the week for study/work purposes. 

Also, I got wifi, but pretty sure it was a neighbor's unsecured network.
author: John E.

description:
Watered down coffee poured by people with ugly attitude!  

What happened to the "latest dripping technology" that they were supposed to be using???  Were they dripping a gallon of water on one single bean of coffee while standing around looking busy and selectively ignoring customers?
author: binh l.

description: Funky lefty coffeeshop. Coffee was ok, but not great.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Went here for the first time last week.  Ordered the iced chocolate mocha expresso drink (very rich).

Service was good, people were nice. We sat there for a while playing on our iTouches since there was free WiFi.

Very chill inside. Lots of seating areas.
author: Lynda L.

description:
The coffee is completely unremarkable.

The only reason to come and get coffee here is to get that warm and fuzzy feel people get when they think they are saving the world via consumerism. 

Oh, and the music they play here blows.
author: Tom W.

description:
As someone who used to work in a coffee shop I seem to have very high standards and for once I can say that this place does fit the bill. One of the best ways to find out if a place makes decent coffee is to taste their drip not the espresso. B/c u can put all the love u want to in the espresso but don't forget about the drip. 

So basically I ordered a drip coffee and was pleasantly surprised, not burned not stale and strong as hell just how I like it. I do appreciate that they had many vegan pastry options. Multiple vegan loafs, cookies and muffins. But to top everything off they definitely had some of the pastries that I used to sell myself at Peet's. Dried fruit & Nut Scone, Fat Free Apricot Oatmeal Vegan Scone, Hazelnut Blackberry Muffin & Banana Blueberry Muffin all courtesy of City Baking. 

I feel like I could do one of three things in this type of cafe... study, smoke a bowl or drink some Mad Dog.
author: Brittany D.

description: Coffee a 2, but ok for a restroom stop to break up day with interesting photos.
author: Jim E.

description: I love this coffee shop. From the activist decor (check out the table tops with vintage political buttons artwork) to the very friendly staff and friendly fellow customers, this is why I moved to Sf. To start a revolution...(okay, to make art for a new revolution) and Coffee to the People is my HQ
author: Twinstar G.

description:
Don't Come Here.

Serious - don't. I have a hard time finding a table at peak times and I don't need any more competition.

It has decent coffee, okay pastries and very fast internet (though it crashes more than at some other places), with lots of tables, reasonably spaced - part of why it was named the best cafe for surfing porn.

I never see people surfing porn there - just way, way too much Facebook - but a lot of people do use it as an office away from the office - including me.

The 1960s/hippie/socially progressive decorations are nice, but they seem a bit less meaningful now that the cafe has changed hands and it is also just a marketing thing rather than anything heartfelt.

The staff is nice and mostly very competent.

There can be issues with the clientele - too many wing-nuts from the street, and recently way too much cigarette smoke blowing in from the street kids hanging around outside.
author: Nick C.

description: There were so many different choices here I didn't know where to start.  I decided to go with the organic hot apple cider which was really tasty.  I waited much longer than most people ordering a chai though.  (That's my usual but I wanted something different.)  The prices are pretty decent and the atmosphere is like any other coffee shop.  It's a good place to stop while walking around Haight on a Sunday afternoon.  I believe your money goes to a good cause so that's an even better reason to support it.  Skip the chains and go here instead if you're in the area.  You'll feel much better about it.
author: Amy J.

description:
The place itself is comfy, as others have said. But the workers are not the nicest. I'm not a huge drink person, so all I wanted was hot water. They charged me .75 cents and gave me a nasty look. Never before have I been charged for water. 

After drinking all that water, I badly had to use the restroom. The woman working told me it was out-of-service, I'm assuming because all I got was water and had been using their internet; I'd seen people using the bathroom, so it was clearly in order.
author: Giulia G.

description:
their roast beef sandwich should really be called "big cow served with some bread."

I know that might make the vegetarians gag, but it makes me gag a little too.  I mean, they really pile on the stuff for you.  

You might finish the sandwich, but you'll know in your head that it's defeated you.
author: Andrew P.

description:
I really like that this place *cares* about good coffee, even if they don't always hit the mark.  Caring is half the battle...My first coffee experience here was pretty good - not as good as Blue Bottle or my beloved Cafe Organica (RIP) - but pretty good.  My second coffee experience was disappointing - perhaps they just needed to recalibrate the machine but the espresso came out bitter and burnt tasting.  Also, I'm baffled by their resistance to the standard two-shot latte (a *must* for serious coffee drinkers). 
All of that said, this place has character and it's one of the few places in my 'hood that respects the bean and fair trade, so i'll be back to give it another go.
author: Ky W.

description:
I don't usually go here, but today I was scared into this establishment by a creepy cowboy.

Let me explain.

I was on my way to Blue Front, or Squat, I hadn't decided which yet, and was heading towards the crosswalk at Masonic when I see the creepy cowboy. He is this older man who hangs out at the liquor store and wears a cowboy hat paired with a light brown leather jacket. He always goes out of his way to say hi to me when I go there, and generally is creepy. Today, I look towards Squat, and there he is, jumping up and down and waving hi to me.

Frightened, I looked across Masonic. I just couldn't walk across Haight because dude skeeved me out so badly. My choices were: Coffee to the People, or Magnolia's. Though the food is very delicious, it is massively overpriced, therefore Maggie's was out of the question. So, CoffeePeeps it was.

The coffee is disgusting. Undrinkable. It tastes like how the coffee always tastes whenever I make it (it's always really horrible when I make it for some reason. I know good coffee when I consume it but I lack to ability to produce it), which is terrible.

(That paragraph was pure poetry.)

The vegan turnover: Also disgusting. It's more like a cardboard pastry wrapped around rubbery, rotten jelly substance than a turnover. Why not use real fruit instead of weird quivering piles of glucose? 

However, the fruit and yogurt thing was delicious. I think I will actually go back there for this, if it's consistantly delicious.

I don't really like the environment though. It's kind of intense. Though, not quite as scary as creepy cowboy.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Let's be honest here.  The baristas must be high, how hard is it to make coffee.    Or, maybe coffee is only good when it's not fair-trade.

For whatever reason I always pretend that I'm vegan when I enter these kinds of establishments.   (I was voted "most likely to conform" in high school, maybe that has something to do with it.)  Anyway, I ordered a vegan chai something or other called Flower Power, it was pretty bad, but I drank it anyway.  It seemed like the right thing to do.   Husband and I split a vegan carrot cake thingy that was deelish, the children had a smoothie and cinnamon roll and decided they don't like cinnamon.   Great.

All in all, I liked the place.    Dinah thought it was a dump but I explained to her that it was artsy and young hipsters like that kind of thing.   She said that she hopes she never gets that way and that garbage is ugly.   

The End.
author: Mimi V.

description:
I thought for sure that they charged me $3 for a large coffee, but now I wonder if this was a mistake.

Nice place.  Too many people intently staring at their laptops as if they had important work to do.  (Somehow, more off-putting than those with their noses in books.)

Still, something false about this place -- artificially political.  Like, if there was a chain store of left-wing coffee shops, this is what it would look like.

(Okay: is this a chain of left-wing coffee shops?  I wouldn't be surprised...)

But, still: I'll take a left-wing coffee shop over the alternative Any Day of the Week.

(Okay, one last thing: "grassroots ambiance?"  Whut?  Would you know a grass root is it bit you in the arse?)
author: V. M.

description:
This is my favorite cafe to "work" in. Even though it's somewhat lively, there's something conducive to productivity in the air for me. Maybe it's the thoughtfully placed posters with inspiring quotes from social revolutionaries; maybe it's the size (which is larger than usual, but not impersonally so); maybe it's all of the open laptops around me. In any case, it's my go-to working cafe.

I think they might have upped the prices ever so slightly recently, and it was never a real steal (if anyone has read more than a couple of my reviews -- which I doubt -- he/she may notice that price is a major preoccupation of mine...) $3.25 for a teapot no bigger than most "large" tea cups at other cafe is a tad steep (pun INTENDED!). But the tea is damn good, and the selection too.

There are a couple of loonies that are looking for an unsuspecting young lady to lend an ear so that they might speak about their relationship to Paris Hilton and Starbucks, but they (he?) tends to be friendly enough. 

Plus one of the women at the counter is from Pittsburgh -- second to Philly on my list of unappreciated cities. 

Finally, I don't feel bad when I stay for more than three hours after ordering only one drink. Should I? What's the protocol here? I always wonder. In the smaller places, I start to feel like I'm hogging the web or something -- even if no one else is there. At Coffee to the People, I typically feel like a model customer -- I don't smell bad, I don't steal, I don't tell others about my relationship with Paris Hilton, and I don't poop on the bathroom floor.
author: Beah B.

description:
I think if you want to work at Coffee to the People, you either need a) various tattoos or b) painful looking facial piercings.

Another recommendation from a SF local, I found this place to be pretty funky.  This was probably the only coffeehouse I ever been to that uses skylights to illuminate the back section.  The front section was as dark as Batman's cave.  The only lighting in the front section was the glare of people's laptops.

It took awhile for me to make up my mind because I wanted something unique that only Coffee to the Peeps offer.  I finally settled on the Mint Matcha Mocha (say that 3 times fast).  Sounds cool and I was hoping that it would taste just as good as the mint mocha I had at Cole Valley Cafe.  It cost me $4.75 so it better taste good!

After my so-so experience from the People's Cafe, Coffee to the People didn't do much to better my day.  The mint mocha tasted like green chalk!  It felt gritty in my mouth and gritty on it's way down!  It had this funny smell of lawn gnomes.  What the hell?!  There were no hints of mint or chocolate!  I ordered a $5.00 cup of @#$%^ grass clippings!

The worst part of it was, half the cup was all foam!  Definitely not my day...
author: Vvn W.

description:
Coffee-based drinks are just average here. The falafel sandwich and side salad was alright and pretty cheap ($4.80). Free wi-fi was nice.

Staff seemed fine. I didn't get any attitude or rudeness from the staff.

As for the atmosphere... The music randomly stops and then starts playing very loudly until a staff notices and turns it down. There's plenty of space for everyone to sit, but the place isn't very clean. The condiments area is messy, tables are somewhat sticky from previous spills and the place has a steady flow of fake hippies and other Haight-streeters. It's true. So sue me.
author: Didi R.

description:
Independent coffee shop, extra points for that, love that it's not a chain.

Good coffee, organic, free trade, and thus a little pricier.

Good place to chill with a book, lots of seating, right in the heart of the Haight Ashbury area.
author: Vickie Y.

description: Coffee to the People -- a coffee shop that, upon walking in, you feel like you are home.  As a student at USF, it became the best place for me to study while staying (highly) caffeinated.  From its cozy interior with comfortable couches and book-lined walls to truly superior coffee, I can safely say that Coffee to the People is one of my favorite coffee stops in San Francisco.  The service can be spotty and sometimes rude, but I guess it's something that sets it apart from corporate coffee chains (and if you're like me and need coffee you'll take what you can get).  Overall, Coffee to the People becomes about the experience, the atmosphere, and the characters you meet while sipping on your delicious beverage.
author: Ashley T.

description: I love hemp milk. I LOVE IT! i love it. I LOVE HEMP MILK! You will to! You have to go here to get it because wholefoods in the devil in hippie's clothing. Google it
author: Jeff K.

description:
The vibe is great.  Nice friendly-hippy, not annoyingly self-righteous-hippy.  The coffee is good quality, not the best, but the large is about the size of a swimming pool, so you do get your moneys worth (if you can drink it before it gets cold).

The bumper sticker wall epitomizes the Bay Area.  There is a sign up, instructing you to bring any bumper sticker you want to the baristas who will decide if the message is consistent with the cafe's beliefs.  Not only do the bumper stickers have to be liberal enough, the baristas are the final arbiter.  Power to the Baristas!
author: Happy C.

description:
This is the only place I have found that makes a great soy latte!!! I love the regular kind, but my stomache doesn't.
Anyways, this place is great- but on the weekend it gets a little crowded and when it gets crowded it gets loud and then I don't want to be there any longer because I can't concentrate on my book.
Oh- and they have vegan food avaliable for those who roll that way.
author: Dangerous T.

description:
The best cayenne hot chocolate I've ever had.

Has wireless.

Cool art.

Friendly staff.

Very me.  Not sure that means anything, but it reminded me of Seattle, so I felt very at home....

I stayed there for an entire afternoon, working on my laptop, feeling alright.  Allllright!!
author: Super M.

description:
I liked this place. I had a white mocha. It was quite good. The coffee was fresh and the whiteness tasted really good too. 

I don't think I was in there long enough to really catch and hoity-toityness.
author: Philip K.

description: I was semi recently blessed with  the gift of being able to linger due to my  lay off.... This is by far my favorite place to linger... sometimes I desire the need to draw inspiration from SF and this is my favorite place to do that... From the wall of liberal bumper stickers, to the free-wifi... this place basically serves as a comfy job search headquarter.... They have tons of veggie options, a tea list to die for, and tons of eye candy..... Some of the staff can be less then interested, but that would never stop me from visiting....
author: Jennifer B.

description:
RUDE. Plain rude.
The coffee is good, but it doesn't matter because the workers are pretentious little nitwits.
Oh wait, they might be nice to you if you've got dreads or a barbell in your face. otherwise, look out!
I went there with my roommate. Ordered, and went to pay. The coins I had were on top of my bill and when the barista/cashier guy took it the coins flew. I apologized. No big deal. Then the barista/cashier guy turns to me and says "Did you really give me 50 cents?"...um no, thats my way of scamming a cheaper coffee. What an A-hole. Thumbs down.
author: melody r.

description:
I've spent many afternoons doing homework here. I guess I should probably rate it 3.5 stars--certainly not perfect, but a good place to hang out. 

-The coffee is pretty good (and their house drinks--try the 'flower power'); however, it's a bit pricey. I'm willing to pay a little extra for responsible business, though, so maybe this is neither here nor there;

-There are several vegan snack options. Unfortunately, most of them don't taste very good. 

-It's often crowded, which is a good sign. Unfortunately, this means that it's not uncommon to wait 15-20 minutes for the bathroom (no joke, and this isn't an isolated incident);
 
-The staff are competent and serve stuff quickly, but they're kind of surly.

-Lots of outlets, very reliable, free wi-fi. Yay!

Definitely worth trying if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Ramon E.

description:
Alright, so this place is one of my favorite coffee places in the entire city and not only because I live one block away (alright, maybe that is part of it).  

Allow me to quickly enumerate some of the great things about Coffee to the People:

(1) Great fuck'n name for a coffee place!
(2) Good music.
(3) Tastey coffee.
(4) Free wifi.
(5) 1 dollar refills.

Con: You cannot smoke by the door.

Conclusion: Even though you can't smoke by the door it is a great place to study or just hang out and people watch.
author: E-dough R.

description: Hard to mess up coffee, but this place was really good and I LOVED the vibe.
author: Ella Graham W.

description: What the heck happened here?  Why did they recently replace the staff with a bunch of unfriendly people who don't know how to make espresso drinks?
author: Erik N.

description: Love this place! i meet my friends here often and i've even had a few casual business meetings here for my start up. Always friendly staff and great mocha lattes!
author: Carla P.

description:
Sometimes I just want a coffee. Sometimes it's just way to damned convenient to just go to Starbucks. I know! It's a large corporation and I should not go there! I should be supporting local places like Coffee to the People. 

Coffee to the People is the ultimate good karma coffee place in San Francisco. Everything is Fair Trade and organic and more importantly, YUMMY! The space is great. It's spacious and there are tons of bookshelves with used books and games!

I can't help selling part of my soul to corporate America, but I do love places like Coffee to the People. Good job peeps! You're a better lot than I.
author: Jackie I.

description: This was one of the first local cafes I  went to when I first moved to the city. I was at Outside Lands 2008 and between this and GG park I was in love. If I lived in the area this would be my out-of-home office. They know their customers by name ( if you go enough that is ) and all around encompass the Haight-Ashbury vibe. Not many places carry a match latte or even know what that is, but Coffee to the People's match latte is BANGIN'.  This is defiantly a get a place to pop into especially after a trip to Magnolia Pub and Brewery across the street.
author: Jes V.

description: The coffee tastes fine. They take a long time to make the coffee even when there aren't many customers. It's a nice place to sit down and enjoy reading a book.
author: Velina V.

description:
... actually switched to this place as my regular bean fixxx.  reEeally picky about milk quality & normally just go to /starbucks or peet's/  if CTP's product wasn't so consistent and tasty! served hot yet still drinkable. 

* ahh! fairly answers that corporate-community "quality of coffee" quandry
* good deal for your dollar if you *likes* your 4-shot espresso drinks
* never seen anyone be shi#y or mean to a regular customer    

hmMm that's X coffee drinks times Y days a week worth of nOt going to the Buck (pedestrian hell) or Peet's (pretentious hell). more places should be doing this level of quality.  i dunno, a utopian ideal: one day, no coffee shop will serve bad coffee.  wow.  what a dreamer :)
author: Herb C.

description:
Really like this place.  Nice atmosphere and good organic fair-trade coffee.   They also offer vegan cookies, dough nuts and other various vegan baked goods.  Also have tofutti cream cheese for bagels :-)
I also really like that the cafe promotes  social justice and political freedom  Definitely one of my favorite cafes
author: Kevin A.

description:
Lots of tables, free wifi, good people watching, free trade coffee.

They have a great collection of teas, but don't know how to steep it. They use steaming hot water for their green tea unless asked not to. I'm also a little concerned with lack of handwashing after touching money or their hair or faces.
Some of the chairs are a little scary dirty looking.
Staff is usually friendly, but I have seen them too caught up in their conversations to work the counter.

Evidently thay are under new ownership as of a couple of months ago. The owner didn't look like a San Franciscan to me.
author: lia k.

description: Good coffee, chill vibe, lots of outlets. So why two stars? WATCH YOUR STUFF HERE PEOPLE!  Yes, that was worthy of yelling. A year ago, some peeps lifted my iPhone right off the little table that I was sitting at.. Before you think, dude you're a dumb-ass, they also lifted two other people's laptops. All within five min. Obviously pro's.
author: dan s.

description:
This place is exactly what you think of a coffee shop on the corner of Haight . masonic , a few blocks down from haight-ashbury....
The art work in their now is some halloween themed crazy stuff (all for sale, local artists), I like it...It's interesting to say the least.. they usually have realy thought provoking pictures or art.. (not the jackson pollock that takes you into yourself..but more like a a smiling baby in africa despite his Kwashiorkor belly with war surrounded...Shit that makes you remember there are other humans out there....beside yourself..reality
The coffee is good.. The selection of teas are out of reality!!!!
If your anxiious need to calm or chill out--Placid dream!! it will put you out..
If you need an upper- darjeeling is delicious and will have you jacked like a crack head at 3 in the morning zipping through your to do list.. The baristas are loud and you know their entire life story within a few minutes of standing in line.. But they are nice and efficient and laid back...The days are better than others, they are human beings, and i love em.. they do a good job.. The custees are quirky and like minded from all walks of life who enjoy coffee in a comforting atostphere. Couches, tables, etc.. They hook up the homeless in there without thinking they are giving away their lives...and it's not a problem for anyone...this place is my favorite place for coffee in the Haight....Free WIFI...The lovelies aren't too bad to see as they come in and out either...oh they do something with grilled chicken now later in the day..its smelled marvelous..tip ur barista (even if its only your change), especially here. Special place..MAD Tea selection....
author: New Dilly G.

description:
Cards on the table: Coffee drinking is a subjective experience. Therefore I shall not pass comment on said topic. Any comments I make shall largely be focused on the aesthetic and atmospheric climate of this establishment. If you are looking for an office away from home then this will suffice in the short term. However, from a functionl perspective, there are a few things lacking

1. The cups and saucers are chipped...always. I have yet to get a cup (15 visits so far) that is not chipped or cracked. If you ask for a replacement you receive a look that makes you feel like you invented capitalism, fungal infections and papercuts.

2. The toilets: There is one and it is eternally busy. Some of the occupants are even customers. I fully appreciate that non-paying customers may need to use the facilities at times but they appear to go in there and hibernate. 

3. The armchairs: I know no other way to say this other than in a forthright manner...they smell. Sit in one for an hour and the distinct smell of BO, sickly perfume, cigarette smoke, sour milk clings to you like a limpet to a schooner. This is especially regretable as they are tremenduously comfortable.

4. The cost: This place is expensive. The most expensive single espresso I have yet found in the three months I have lived in SF. On a plus side it is the only place I have been to in the US that heats its espresso cups prior to filling them. Long may such a habit last

However:

This is a great place to people watch. A good cross section of society drifts in here and usually, most announce their arrival. On any given day I estimate 45% of the patrons are smply there so they can be looked at while they work...and there is nothing wrong with that.
author: Neil W.

description:
This is one of the best cafes I have been to in San Francisco. The Flower Power drink is a fantastic mix of espresso, chai and soy milk, and it has the perfect kick. The atmosphere is chill and laid back, and it isn't always crowded with hipster tourists.

*edit: The Flower Power with almond milk instead of soy is even better and healthier :)

Also, they have delicious vegan donuts.
author: Theresa T.

description: Awesome! The staff is great and the food/coffee/tea is nothing short of amazing. Oh and free wifi! A great rest and recuperation point on my journey on foot up Haight St.
author: Möhammad C.

description: My friends and I only came in thinking there was a public bathroom-- there isn't one. But there is a bathroom for customers, so my friend bought a chocolate peanut butter cookie and a corn cake.  The cookie was delicious but the corn cake was dry.  It seems like a cool hippie place to either work on your laptop or hang with friends.  I did like looking at all the artwork on the walls.
author: Leslie C.

description: I really enjoy going to CTTP before work in the mornings. They are so down to earth and not pretentious at all. They are nice to the homeless people and let them do odd jobs around the cafe. The food is really yummy and the staff are usually really friendly. The iced latte on its own tastes pretty burnt sometimes, but I have decided to go with the frozen latte (not like a frappucino at all) and its REALLY good. Not too sweet or bitter. There are few creepy guys that sit there for hours just starring at you, and yes i mean directly at you with no reading materials or plans to do anything but stare, but I guess this just adds to the cafe's character.
author: whitney D.

description: Their coffee is really good and as one reviewer said, piping hot. Austin and Laura are friendly to the regulars. Couches are not such a good idea when many homeless folks tend to roost there, though.
author: Eileen M.

description:
1 Star for the Chocolate to the people! Love this drink. 

Other than that this place would rock if the staff wasn't so damn rude! It sucks for those of us that live in the hood to have a place that would be nice to go to, but you don't cause you don't need or to deal with the employees attitudes! Guess i'll be traveling down to Lower Haight to Cafe International where they never give any attitude.
author: Savannah C.

description: Yummy coffee, but the bench I sat on wasn't so kind on my butt. After surfing the web and doing homework for a couple of hours, it was a bit of a task to get up and going. I should have sat on their couch, but it was full. Sadness. BUT, this place seriously has some killer coffee.
author: Janae L.

description: My quest for the perfect coffee house in San Francisco  has ended with Coffee to the People. It provides a cozy atmosphere for studying, with constant, low-level ambient sound but not *too much* noise. The drinks are good, especially their hot chocolates, yum! And the political emphasis is an inspiration, and reminds me of why I want to be a librarian in the Bay Area.
author: Jill H.

description: I love the bumper sticker wall.  It's roomy; there's plenty of seating--a great place to work or chat.  Organic/fair trade coffee is always a plus.  And vegan pastries are an even bigger plus.  If you're in the Haight and jonesin' for a caffeine fix, look no further.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Woohoo!  It's my first San Francisco review!  I spent all morning working here and it's a great place - points for free wireless and great coffe, but I like the social justice theme as well.  Cool posters on the walls and tables with inspirational messages, fun staff and yummy croissoints.  Wasn't crowded when I was there, but it was 9am on a saturday - damn jet lag.
author: Sam P.

description: I am going to have to agree with the majority of reviews.  the coffee is excellent and the atmosphere is very nice.
author: big c.

description: My favorite place to enjoy a nice cup of coffee and read a book or newspaper. Too many hipsters in there sometimes with their laptops due to the free wi-fi. They always have great music playing too!
author: David A.

description: Something about this place just feels right. The atmosphere, art (and other) books on the bookshelves by the comfortable couches - nice mix of people.... I think this is probably one of my favorite hang-out spots in SF (and one of the best coffee shops in town, definitely).
author: Kevin P.

description: Although at first I avoided this place because I missed the late Kona Shores, I have found myself frequenting Coffee to the People with pleasure.  The staff is nice and the coffee is organic and fair trade.  Finally a place that really focuses on the health and well being of people.
author: Dana C.

description:
I just waited for over 5 minutes someone to take my order, even though there were two able bodied people behind the counter who seemed to be doing nothing except avoiding me and telling dumb jokes to each other.  Once my order was taken, it took another 3 minutes to pay because they guy kept dashing off to help his coworker with something non-coffeeshop related.  Today is typical of my experience here -- fine coffee, so-so food, and just the absolutely.  slowest.   service.  EVER!  This is definitely not a place to come for a quick coffee -- I've been here during the morning rush, and I always wonder if the people who are waiting in line don't actually have jobs.

Update 11/9/06: the owner sent me a really nice email regarding the above experience.  She offered me a coffee on the house and made some promising comments regarding more efficient service.  I'll hold off on increasing my rating till there is a noticeable difference (the experience above is typical of my visits there), but I'm definitely giving them a second (actually, 40th) chance.  I should also add that the people who work there are really friendly when they do finally notice you waiting.

Update 11/16/06: The two star rating sticks.  Today I ordered a Peppermint Mocha.  After paying $4.10 (wtf, a gallon of milk costs less than this) and waiting for 10 minutes, I realized that 3 people who were after me in line had received their drinks.  I went to check at the counter and the girl was like, "Oh! You never got your drink? Oops." I will keep coming here for the location factor, but it will be for drip coffee during off hours only!
author: pitter k.

description: This is exactly the kind of cafe I like when I need to do a bunch of work but don't feel like sitting at home to do it. You can choose from couches or tables and power outlets are a-plenty. On top of that, they have tasty coffee - granted, I'm no coffee connoisseur but there are not that many places that will serve you decaf that hasn't been sitting in a pot all day and end up tasting like a dirty towel.
author: Angi C.

description: Sandwiches are getting smaller and matcha tea isn't made as strong as it used to.  Their pumpkin pie late was awful.
author: Susan K.

description: The first time i walked in to coffee to the people i was a little thrown off by the people.Don't let that throw you off. Now i go there everyday to do my computer work and have a nice hot cup of coco! Or sometimes in the morning a Golden Gate ( 3 to 4 shots of coffee with a twist..... an orange twist with whipped cream and shaved orange peels) it's delicious!!! Once i started talking to the people i got to like them a lot. Very friendly and funny. It's best enjoyed when it's pouring rain outside and your watching it from the window sipping on a hot drink. Thank you coffee to the people!
author: Waheguru Singh K.

description: Although I'm a semi-organic eater, this is the first place I drank a coffee when I moved here in SF. It was a random time too. Their coffee isn't bad at all, I ordered coffee and my friend ordered a hot chocolate. Both drinks were made very well and tasted great! Go grab a hot drink, especially when you just got done roaming around Haight.
author: Eunice B.

description: The coffee is superb - finally Upper Haight residents get a freaking break from the dirty water that is served at other coffee shops that will remain nameless but in my typical curmodgeon like fashion don't really l ike all the political stickers plastered on the wall. I have a strong opposition to political slogans and stickers, even when I agree with them (for the most part). Perhaps it's the fact that I was overwhelmed with hippie politics in my three years at Oberlin or perhaps it's the fact that I don't want to think about anything too profound before I've had my daily infusion of caffeine. Maybe it's both. Anyway, I will continue to patronize Coffee to the People, I'll just get it to go.
author: Maria D.

description: I love it here! They serve fair trade coffee and it's delicious.  the atmosphere is great!  i would spend hours over the weekends to study for finals and midterms and write term papers before I graduated. It's got a lot of character and though I am no longer in school, I can sit there for hours, drink coffee, people watch and write.  You guys should go check it out!
author: Anne M.

description: I have come here a couple of times to have coffee/tea and while the drinks are pretty good, the service hear is rude...I am not sure what the deal is but the girls are never really friendly...or is it just me???
author: Denny R.

description: Good tea, comfortable, casual space. Plenty of tables, sofas, and even a library of games and books. Lots of outlets and free wireless too. A nice place to get a cup, hang out, and relax
author: Pat T.

description: Not only do they have several vegan desserts (we had the yummy apple pie), but when I asked if I could get hot chocolate with soymilk, I was asked if I wanted vegan whipped cream with it! Thus prompting my (also vegan) husband to say to the server, "I love you", as I thought the same... Can't believe we haven't visited this place before! :-)
author: Pax G.

description: There are so many coffeehouses in this city - but this one gets points for the wonderful staff, the cozy welcoming atmosphere, the great coffee and the Friday night open mics (7:30pm -10) are really, really good. Very impressive - and the free wi-fi never hurts!
author: Amber B.

description: A very good coffee experience. Great atmosphere - I loved the bumper stickers on the wall. The decor was pretty nice for an unpretentious place. The quiche was pretty good, as were the smoothies. I thought that the coffee was well above average, and the breads were excellent. If there weren't a lot of coffee shops closer to me, I would come here all the time.
author: Dana L.

description: Like those coffeeshops on sitcoms, only the patrons are far less witty.
author: Mike O.

description:
I walked into Coffee to the People at 2 p.m. on a foggy Saturday afternoon and I had a moment. This was possibly the most mellow coffee shop atmosphere I have ever seen. The vibe was way more opium den than coffee shop. This is caffeinated San Francisco? I seriously had to look out the window to make sure I hadn't somehow been beamed to Portland.*

The Beach Boys were blasting on the stereo system, which was a little disconcerting. The Beach Boys are one of those things where you either love them or hate them. I myself am a lover, but I think out of respect for the other half, I would hesitate before subjecting an entire room of strangers to them at that volume. It became clear to me fast, though, that the tatted up barista who was running the show cared little for the common people to whom she served coffee. 

As I waited quite a while for my small latte, I listened to her complain about how hot she was. Imagine being hot while standing crammed behind a counter in front of an espresso machine while steaming milk! I have personally put in many, many hours at the helm of an industrial sized espresso machine, and let me tell those who are not in the know- it's not even remotely chilly. The barista barked a command at a smaller, clearly intimidated co-worker to "go out there and open the front doors- both of them!" Small, intimidated barista obliged, but paused mid-scurry to inform the tatted up barista that the coffee shop- you know, the part where the paying customers hang out - wasn't hot like it was behind the counter, and people might get cold. To which tatts replied "Open the doors anyway. People won't be very happy if the workers pass out and can't do their job."  Ah, warm fuzzies all around.

I finally got my latte and stirred in some sugar, at which point I was faced with the perplexing decision about which of the 5,000 different bins to throw the stirrer away in. Lucky for me, they each had a list of all the different things you could throw away on each one. After a mere 30 minutes or so of reading, I discovered that my stirrer should go into the "Compost" bin. I surely didn't want to throw it in the trash, where a sign made it clear that you were single handedly filling the world with evil landfill if you threw anything -ANYTHING- in that bin. Call me crazy, but why not have spoons available so the people can stir their coffee with something that doesn't need to be thrown away?

As I was leaving, another barista emerged from the back and called out "Half of a vegan sandwich!" and plopped a plate down on the counter, then turned to walk away without a backward glance.

Three stars to Coffee to the People for sheer chuckle value. It's not often that a place can defend the earth and disregard it's human patrons with  equal vigor and aplomb. 

*Footnote: I absolutely adore Portland, so Portlanders, don't get your panties in a bunch.
author: Angie R.

description: Yes, it's a Haight Street coffee shop with politics all over the walls and free wifi.  The room was full of people with laptops, one to a table.  There's also a couch and some armchairs in the back.  We settled at a larger table for two -- no wait that was two tables pushed together -- and enjoyed the great food.  The "non-traditional miso" soup was a great chunky vegetable soup, and the ham & cheese sandwich was twice as big as I expected.  They get extra points for putting cappuccino in a real cappuccino cup.
author: David D.

description: This place is awesome and has a lot of character, with all of its posters of important revolutionary characters throughout history that fought for human rights and other things. The walls are also lined with shelves with all sorts of books and board games. They have free WiFi so there are a lot of people with their laptops in there, enjoying the great organic, free-trade coffee and pastries! I have tried their soy chai lattes and organic apple cider and both were wonderful! Their walnut rum pie is a heart-stopper- that's how AMAZING it is. They also have a great vegan selection. last time I went they had vegan carrot spice cake, vegan scones and cookies, among other things. I will definitely make Coffee to The People a spot that I will hit regularly, whenever I am in the area.
author: Daniela A.

description: I'm bracing myself for the hate mail.  Word to the People... this is not good coffee.  Oh so average.  Several visits have not changed my mind.  The lunch fare is great.  The atmosphere is pleasant.  And they do make an awesome latteccino.  Cappuccino?  Lattes?  Even regular coffee?  Not so good.  That's it.  I'm not going to say anything else.  I am afraid of the bad karma it will bring me.
author: sarah k.

description: Decent coffee and atmosphere but it was freezing cold because they left the door open. Also, no TP!
author: Travis L.

description: I'm a bit biased because of the location (30 second walk from work), but this is a great, unpretentious coffee shop.  It seems to be doing good business, but I like that there is always a place to sit and something to read.  The staff is friendly and un-snobbish (I sadly can't say the same for many of the other merchants in the Haight).
author: Emma K.

description: Probably my favorite neighborhood cafe though Rockin Java comes close. I love the atmosphere/decor...it's cozy, but not stifling. And the food is great, as is the tea. Good service too. (I don't drink coffee so I can't comment on that.) The free WiFi is nice too.
author: Barbs J.

description:
Their Coffee is great! I have had really enjoyable weekends here with friends. 

But.

My pet peeve occurred here and it gave me flashbacks to what I detested about living in Santa Cruz. I came here to do a little writing on my computer on a weekday early evening and it was full of weirdos and one guy even came up to my table and sat down across from me (it was a very small table) and began to talk without shutting up. I know that I am a very nice and open person and thus I attract weirdos - but it has been my goal to repel them recently with strong protective energy forces and dirty looks . I seriously gave this man some nice understanding while firmly first hinting that I need to do my work, and then saying please stop talking I need to do my work. After ten minutes of finishing his story about meeting a woman in  a hotel, he finally stopped blubbering and sat across the way staring at me. I was pissed. I paid a lot for my Darjeeling tea - like four bucks - and now I was leaving right away b/c as much as I try and create my own world - this man was freaking me out, and there were weirdos everywhere. 

I may sound paranoid and if I do - you just don't understand. 

However, there were very nice people minding their business too, but I just wouldn't go here during the week to do work - EVER!

Come here on a weekend for a fun vibe and some comfy couches and good coffee.
author: Sari G.

description: I like the drip coffee a lot ($1.50 for a small, but it feels like a medium!).  I like the couches in the back and the bookshelves filled with books, boardgames, and other thangs to keep patrons coming back for non-coffee stuff.  I like the political bumper stickers and icons on the wall.  I like the tables.  The bathroom is freakin dope--it's really spacious and CLEAN!  CLEAN!  and also very pretty.  Gawsh... people with iBooks and Powerbooks seem to be multiplying everywhere... they're just so ubiquitous!
author: Grace M.

description: Yelpers, sucked me into trying another place!  This is a cool place to study around Haight street.  The organic\fair trade mocha wasn't as good as the organic whip cream on top!  Free wi-fi, but why close at 8pm during the week?  Nice and bright to do your reading, but they could use larger tables.  Overall,  a new spot to study \surf the web over good tasting coffee!
author: Jason A.

description: When I was an insomniac, they fueled me with espresso.  I was bouncing off the walls from the fabulous caffinatedness of it all.
author: Becky P.

description: I LOVE this place. Good, strong, well made coffee + free wifi. What more could you want? How about free trade coffee delicious food, books and board games for your perusal? Well they've got that too. On of my favorite cafes in all of SF. Which is saying something.
author: Rhi G.

description: I went in there today with my cousin to escape from the rain- hadn't been for a couple years, although not much has changed. Very nice workers, good coffee, good books, and good board games. definitely one of my faves.
author: Sandra L.

description: Pretty neat place. They had some interesting looking drinks. My gf and I got the mint green tea mocha something or the other. It was pretty yummy. The girls behind the counter were pretty unwelcoming and rude. I think they could tell we were NOT vegan or even vegetarian.  Hey, aren't meat eaters allowed to have good service??  But seriously, whatever the reason was, they were not nice and seemed to be in their own world.
author: Goose M.

description: My previous review of Coffee to the People shed light on what I perceived to be a disinterested, disconnected clientele.  When I stopped in more recently, I saw a group of girls sitting at a big table, chatting and knitting!  Quite cool.  So I feel better about this coffee place than I did before, and I'll definitely continue patronizing it.  And as I said in my original review, the espresso drinks are freaking great.  Try the flower power!
author: Brett N.

description: All you 4 and 5 star reviewers are outta your minds, this gets 3 stars at most, and not for the coffee.  Granted, i've only been there once, but that was enough.  I was drawn in by the comfy look and the *free trade* agenda.  This sort of deception is my weakness (I once believed they took "gullible" out of the dictionary when someone told me that, too.)  Don't fall for it!  The cappucino was bitter and burnt, the mocha was more sickningly sweet than anything at Star*@!&s, and the chai was all bite and no taste.   The space was pleasant, but it was also a bit odd because it looked like somone with anal tendencies over-consciously styled it to look disorganized.
author: Today Y.

description: I love the fact they have really strong coffee here and FRESH carrot juice. I love carrot juice. The breakfast here is ok. I am not a fan of the line.  The staff is nice and I really feel for these hardworking people. They need a better system. They always seem to be in the weeds. Overall it is a great cafe. It does get crowded on weekends. AT least you are not the chode waiting outside pork store on haight st.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Though I enjoy the couches, fair trade and organic, multiple vegan options for drinks and baked goods, the service here is pretty bad. The baristas exist in their own world,  involving each other, the music, or their friends leaning on the counter telling loud stories over the noise of the steamer. When they do decide to acknowledge the line slowing piling up, it is with terse, slightly clueless service, totalling with hyperbolic prices and slow delivery. Though it's only a couple blocks from my house, I rarely visit, instead opting for the slightly better choices several blocks away.
author: isaak b.

description: Although i fixate on an isolated image of a nude "Corky" from Life goes on holding a plastic hamster cage, bellowing " COFFEE......TO......DA......PEOPLEEEEE!" I can ruefully meddle through these infantile fantasies to procure me a patio-sized double decker hummus supermarket-on-a-loaf along with a vegan cookie shake to smoosh the carb leviathan. I would huff gas for an hour to build up interest for this kind of moderate brilliance, any day.
author: Christopher J.

description: I am a semi-regular there. The coffee is good, not the best.
