The service from the mostly Gothic girl staff is variable, they can be moody but I have had pleasant service most of the time.  The wi-fi service is excellent and they don't seem to mind if you park your ass there for a long time. The circuit and router are robust and you can zip through web pages and download torrents files fast . Seems a lot of homeless people hang around the door and sometimes in the place but I have no problem with that, hey its Haight-Ashbury. They could do a better job in their bathroom. Go for the good free wi-fi attitude and less for the product. And its a good place to people watch too.
author: Mike K.

description: Went to walk around Haight with boyfriend and some friends and decided to get something hot to drink. Every time we walk around Haight St Ive always wanted to try this place so I finally got the chance to and ordered myself a Vanilla Soy Latte. How delicious it was!!! even though it was a little pricey I thought it was worth it.
author: Tracy A.

description: Excellent coffee.  Nice, progressive vibe.  And free Wi-Fi!  Great place to sit down & stay a while (and  in fact, I do this often).  I'd give this place 4 stars if it weren't for the ABSOLUTELY HORRIBLE music that they seem so bent on playing all day long, at full volume.  It's just muthafuckas screaming through an entire song!  What, have these people got something against MELODY?  It is really, REALLY terrible!  Makes it very difficult to concentrate or focus.  Perhaps this is their way of ensuring that no one stays too long?  You should really take this into consideration before you come to this cafe, and perhaps bring a iPod or laptop with some headphones & YOUR OWN music, to preserve your sanity.  Otherwise, it's cool.
author: Eric H.

description: I am a coffehouse freak. When I come to S.F., I will drive miles to have my coffee here. It is a very cool place with good coffee, ambience, and music -- not to mention very cool neighborhood.
author: Robert D.

description:
Update:  raised my rating to 5 stars and have elected to call this place "Coffee for the Communists"

This place is the goods.  A perfect place to hang out for a few hours.

Initially deducted one star b/c the cashier has a few too many piercings and a forrest of underarm caused a little awkwardness, but I haven't seen this person in a month.  

Very laptop friendly environment (ie the abundance of electrical outlets)
author: WP D.

description: I am only reviewing the regular brewed coffee.  I have no idea of their fair trade policies (although I"m guessing I would be for, not against) or how good the wi fi is, or any of the snacks.  I just think its the best coffee in this area.
author: b s.

description: The best coffee in Haight-Ashbury, Cole Valley, and probably the Western Addition. The people are usually friendly and laid-back, nice to everyone. And whenever I go in, usually in the morning, they're playing awesome classic rock'n'roll. The vegan doughnuts are delicious. You win, CTTP.
author: Henry M.

description:
Oh, travesty, for the great bastion of hippie chintz - one of hte few left in the Haight - has been sold.  Formerly run as a cooperative, the employees here are losing their benefits.  Fie, I say. Fie.  Minus one star for you. 

I adore this place, everything from the hideous art, including the macrame oceanscape, to the wallfull of bumperstickers (your slogan here!) to the tacky couches and the nonlending library.  Its ugly, they burn their food, and there's not a shred of self conscious hipster about it.  They make a good latte, and have a good tea selection, and make no effort to be consumptively cool.  It is, in a word, totally perfect.
author: Becka R.

description:
So I'm one of those Starbucks freaks out there. But every time I come here to get a white mocha (which sometimes comes with RAINBOW SPRINKLESSS!!!)... i feel like passing out because the coffee just tastes so freakin good... and it makes me forget that Starbucks even exists. If I could, I would just come here all the time.. but I can't cuz it's too far. 

As for the place, it's pretty cool. They got all sorts of art on one side of the wall that they sometimes change up .. and lots of stickers on the other. Some couches for you to sit on and even game boards for you to play with.  I think they also do open mic nights sometimes? I'm not sure but I think i saw a little ad about it in there one time.  Whatever.. I could care less about the place cuz i take my drink to go..  and the cashiers/baristas seem kinda blah but i still give this place 5 stars because I really love the coffee.
author: Mila B.

description:
update to the review below that I made earlier in the year is: "the baristas are still awesome, the owners smile but are spurious, and they'll close in a year and a half. im betting on a new shoe store. get the matcha tea still!

***************************************
I used to work here and let me say for a FACT THAT IT IS FREAKISHLY GOOD CLEAN.  Megan who runs the place is all about cleanliness, freshness, and all those good ness's.  

The staff are easy going and aiming to please, and since I've left I've returned ever so often and drink the heavenly soy matcha latte.  In addition to the good people i got to know behind the counter before I left, the new baristas are always kind and trying to make the best cup of coffee.  although one person always seems scary to me, order! order now! move move move.  and no i wont look at you because i can't, can't can't.  but this can also be turned into a plus, because they just want to give everyone the coffee goodness (there's that ness thing again).  A good atmosphere, usually good music to listen to, and your co-coffee drinking people in the next table are usually pondering a good thought or reading a good book. free wi-fi, good connection, bring your lap top. oh & A LOT of good tables to choose from. 

and this is my  1st yelp back talk moment - to sara g. who wrote

" the way workers and the environment (not to mention the animals) are exploited in the meat industry is FAR worse than in the coffee industry."

yeah, lets compare torture. Chidren working/harvesting all day, families that are being forced off lands and they can't afford to buy food - and the horrors of the meat industry are true but again, lets not compare torture.

and. end. scene.
author: Walrus C.

description: Great coffee, love the free internet, adore the wall posters, but do not dig unclean couches and tables.
author: Cara D.

description: Need to review for http://www.yelp.com/list_details?favorites_list_id=xJ_tC-4_YAdDCurRxaQBNw&fsid=d78qkra22poTIy-UJd557Q
author: chad n.

description: I came for the atmosphere and wifi, and was a little disappointed. Did not seem to be a enough wifi to go around. One of the owners was helpful -- he did the old reliable "problem determination" step of turning it off and then back on. Now, I am enjoying the wifi.
author: Lloyd D.

description:
I know that there's a gazillion (so I exaggerate a little) coffee shops in San Francisco, but I'm usually drawn to this one (if I'm not selling out and buying Starbucks).
There's free wireless and a good cup of coffee, as well as a bunch of sitting options, from standard tables to comfy sofas and chairs with lower tables. However, my favorite part about this place is the awesome game selection (Boggle, Scrabble, Scattergories, etc.) - assuming that you're going with a friend or two to play with. My personal favorite is the Trivial Pursuit from sometime during the Cold War. Don't answer Russia; it's the Soviet Union. And make sure you choose either East or West Germany. I guess it's fitting though - since from the name alone it's clear that Coffee to the People is going for the Communist vibe.
A tip: If you're going to play games, bring some pens (and paper) with you because there's not that much lying around.
author: Rachel L.

description: A nice collection of bumperstickers on the wall.  A nice collection of people also.   I couldn't tell though, which people were "the people" and which were just dressed that way.   Some of the people looked  kind of like a  lot of people I know who are just one paycheck away from being counted among  "the people."  When that happens, they'll have more time for coffee but might not be able to afford it.  When the revolution comes, maybe there will be a more visible difference in coffee shops which provide coffee "for" the people and those which provide it "to" the people.  Until such lines are drawn,  the proletariat and the bourgeoisie may both be found here, indistinguishable, even in their preference for low fat creamer.
author: David H.

description: I love this place because it makes you feel like you live in a small town. I really love to sit here and work, check email, chat  with friends, drink coffee. It's the kind of place where you lounge and linger, not like Starbucks, where it's all about the coffee. There are also performers on Tuesday nights, so, if you are bored or lonely or alone on a Tuesday night, it's a nice place to go to relax and get out and see people. It's a good neighborhood joint, I say.
author: Elizabeth R.

description: oh yeah, it doesn't hurt that they have the cutest boys working here either.
author: Daniel S.

description: More about being one of the few mellow coffee shops in the Haight than actually making good coffee.  I live nearby, so I've gone lots of times for convenience alone.  The milk and/or soy is ALWAYS scalded beyond tastebud endurance and today I was served a medium in-house in a smaller-than-medium chipped cup that didn't fit into the chipped saucer that was handed with it.  If you must get your coffee here, get it to go unless you have nothing better to do on Haight than play a boardgame in a coffee house or get your public WiFi on.
author: N. L.

description: Let's see.  Great atmosphere, lots of comfy couches.  Food and caffeinated products.  Free Wi-Fi.  Posters of Mandela, Gandhi, Einstein, and Harriet Tubman.  What's not to like?  Around the corner from the famed Haight Ashbury.  Not the ideal place to study since they will always have some music going and there is a lot of people roaming in and out, but if you're just doing some light work on your computer or are hanging out with friends after spending time in the Haight, this is a great place to check out.  Prices are very reasonable and it is just a fun place to be.
author: Kenton W.

description: They have my second favorite mint tea in the city.  Sometimes it's in first place depending on my mood.  The competition for tables is fierce and a little bit silly.  People frequently reserve tables before getting on line to order.  This creates a backlog of confused people who already have their tea/coffee/etc and are looking for a place to sit only to find tables "reserved".  A little attitude adjustment in two directions (staff and patrons) and this place would easily get another star.
author: Melissa Y.

description: I give this place 2 stars since it is near where I live and I can always find a table to get some work done while jammin out on my ipod.  BUT I will say these people need to cut the attitude.  seriously.  I am tired and grumpy  before my coffee too, but you have been at work and you probably have some in you by the time I get there.  The music reminds me that I live San Fran after all and helps me shrug off the staff.
author: S L.

description: Cute shop, very boho.  I didn't really care for my green tea, however.  The people who were working there seemed really nice and helpful.  My sister had a mint tea, which she said was really good.
author: Sarah F.

description:
So they have yummy vegan donuts...cool.   They also have good organic coffee...great.  Their service is........................................................ok.    Finally, their iced mocha's have made me a repeat customer.

UNFORTUNATELY, their clientele can lick my fucking o-ring!  Half of the patrons are overwhelmingly confused tourist and the rest our the extra pompous, rude Haight-breed hipsters.  

FACTS OF THE CASE:  Like many other sad bastards shopping The Haight I was in dire need of a piss reciprocal.  So I stopped at C to the P
to take a pee and so I wouldn't seem like a non-customer dead beat, my girl was nice enough to buy me coffee while I did my business.
As I expected there was a line for the WC.  I asked the rather distraught looking tourist & his son in front of the bathroom if I was in the bathroom line, he said yes and that they'd been waiting for 15 minutes.
I then hear a "hey" behind me and I see this hipster bitch lying on this love seat.  "I'm in line, will you respect my line," she says with an air of condesendence that could only come from someone who has been told they were pretty their whole life.  I wanted to be like Patrick Bateman and tell her she was an ugly bitch but her boyfriend was standing next to her.  He gave me a sympathetic "it is not worth arguing with her, bro," look so I just said whatever.
Now I am ready to piss my pants and I began to wonder if these idiots bothered to ASK FOR THE KEY.  No, no they did not, I asked for it.  
Fuck.

CONCLUSION:  Tourists I can except to be ignorant but that hipster was just being a lazy SLUT!!!
author: ray M.

description: I'm not a big fan of the Haight, but I did live there for a couple of months, and this is where I eventually decided to get coffee in the morning before starting my search for a place to live that wasn't in the Haight. I must compare this place to the People's Cafe, since the names are so similar. People's has a better selection of food, and is open later than To The People, however, the WiFi at To The People has no password, whereas at People's, I had issues getting the password to work. To The People has a free library, which is actually pretty good, whereas, People's has no entertainment other than the quirkiness of the regulars. The most important distinction is that, due to To The People's location, there are significantly less Euro-tourists than at People's. If you're looking for a quiet place to enjoy a reasonably priced egg and cheese bagel, this is your spot in the Haight.
author: Zibdabity B.

description:
being the wifi nomad that i am, i'm constantly on the lookout for those "free wifi" signs in cafes' windows.  but i don't often walk by Coffee to the People, so i didn't notice it was even there, much less if they have wifi or not.  turned out they were having a screening of "The Ground Truth" and i offered to help.  so then i checked them out online and saw that they are much more that a coffee shop w/ free internet and a bathroom that EVERYONE can use (including the homeless - try finding another business on haight street that will allow that!)

the couple who owns the place, karin and bob, seemed like very nice people, and i love that that they've shaped their business to be in line w/ what they believe in.   and they offer fair trade organic coffee and tea, organic and vegetarian food options, and these specialty coffee concoctions like "flower power" (a vegan blend of espresso, chai and soy milk) and "freak out" (4 shots of espresso w/ a defribulator on the side)...i had to lay down after the flower power, not for the weak of heart.

they have lots of places to sit, and i do sit, for hours sometimes, working on my computer.  they also have couches in the back and one in the front for lounging while reading one of their many socially conscious book options from their library...

i've never been but i hear they have open mic nights on Tuesdays from 7-9.  and their vibe is so neighborhoody, so NOT starbuckian, and they feature local art for sale on their walls (as well as posters of people like cesar chavez and ghandi and bumper stickers like "question authority" and "peace is patriotic").
author: Suzanne A.

description: Why can't I decide? This is only two blocks from my house, so I know I will back regardless of how I feel today, tomorrow, next week. Sometimes the almost too strong, too organic coffee is good and at other times I feel it's terrible. Sometimes I love the really spicy chai that hits the back of my throat and sometimes I wish it were a bit sweeter. Sometimes I feel the need to spend $5 on a flower power coupled with a bagel more vegan than I thought possible. Overall, I come here, but I think it's out of convenience rather than thinking they offer something great.
author: Alicia J.

description: GREAT coffee, great hang out space, and friendly service.  I spend time here b/c it's a cool, delicious, and socially & envirnomentally conscious. Check it out!
author: kyle w.

description: Okay, this is just weird.  The coffee is decent if that.  Don't understand the rants and raves.  Food fine.  Service fine.
author: Marla L.

description: I came here sunday morning just to get a vegan dough nut. There was people in there and there was a line, but it wasn't that long. The dough nut costed me $1.75, my boyfriend thought I was crazy for paying that much for a dough nut, it is the same price as Rainbows. The pastries there seemed good, I am going to go back to try their coffee cake.
author: Janet Z.

description: Loud music.  Mediocre coffee.  Small tables.  Plus one star for free WiFi.
author: Eric S.

description:
i'll have to agree with sara g. i was expecting to be blown away but it kind of seemed like the basic run-of-the-mill coffee shop. definitely nice decor, very comfy, plenty of tables, lots of light.

i came in at 3pm with a friend, and we took a few moments deciding what we wanted. there was no one else in line or ordering drinks, food, etc. there were 3 people behind the counter, and when we approached it, money in hand, no one paid any attention to us for several minutes. finally, one of the women behind the counter saw that we were patiently waiting and asked, "can i help you?" i never like to be too critical of customer service, but everyone working there was rather humorless. almost every peet's or starbucks i've been to has a much more upbeat staff.

i ordered the large iced tea which was tasty -- had a bit of fruityness to it that i wasn't expecting (i was thinking it would be more like regular black tea).

i'll definitely go back and give it another try, because i'm curious as to what everyone thinks is so fantastic there. am i missing something?
author: Jill M.

description: I miss Manhattan Bagels. When they were there, the workers rocked, the bagels rocked (why can't we have fresh bagels in the neighborhood??) and they had the right attitude with the neighborhood (they made the stinky people leave).
author: Jeremy P.

description: The cashier/barista/cafe madam was all giggly and perky when a regular babbled on and on about some painting or whatever and I was in line for a good 4-6 minutes with only a one other in front of me. The cafe madam was short and stoic when I got up to the counter and I asked if she had a certain syrup blah blah I had to repeat like 5 times. Then we I decided on hazelnut she was like "the milk! or the syrup!?" Well I tried the milk ... but  who the f knows about hazelnut milk ...? wtf don't speak to me like I'm supposed to know that jeez take a chill pill or lay off the quad shots already. The latte was good and I liked the hazelnut milk but it's not my favorite cafe in SF but maybe in Haight/Ashbury area. I guess go there prepared next time...
author: Carissa M.

description: I've only been here a few times, which is a tragedy since I live only a few blocks away, but this place is great. First, their coffee is great. It can be hard to find a good cup of black coffee, and they do it right. Second, the place has a totally awesome atmosphere. with all of the couches, chairs, books, games, etc., you can't help but just hang around for a few hours. You should definitely check this place out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Nick R.

description: The food is not that great and the coffee mocha is nothing to write about. But what makes this different from other coffee houses is the super fast wireless internet! I downloaded a 63 Mb podcast to my iTunes in two minutes! There are a lot of electrical outlets, but it sometimes gets too crowded, especially during the weekends. Other coffee houses with wireless internet have no outlets. There are comfortable chairs and tables in front or sofas in the back next to the small library. Make sure you don't fall asleep on them.
author: herm p.

description:
annie brought me here, but i didn't go inside, just sat in the car. she had a mint m... mocha (forgot the 2nd word) but it was freaking good!

my house coffee was just like any other place.
author: Ameer N.

description: I love this place. I'm from Eugene and this place feels like home cuz it's all hippied out, with political stickers & other paraphernalia all over the place.  CTTP forces me to do my homework. Luckily it's so close to my house or I wouldn't get shizz done...ever. It's your basic coffee house, but they serve organic and fair trade coffee/tea and have like 5 milk alternatives...so bomb. The food is great too...lots of vegan options.
author: Alicia O.

description: vegan carrot loaf BEYOND DRY.  their explanation -- it's vegan.  ummm . . . okaaayyyyy . . . . they also said i wasn't the only one to complain that item was DRY and that others have not complained.
author: Fuji F.

description: I have no idea why the people are giving this place five stars.  It isn't exceptional.  My smoothie was ok, as was my quiche.  Nothing to write home about.
author: Joanna S.

description: Nice little coffeehouse on the Upper Haight with oodles of games, lots of nice couches, and Games Night every first Saturday of the month.  Coffee was great.  Very comfortable, nice atmosphere.
author: Apollo L.

description:
i don't even drink coffee but C to the P is... C for the Me. holler. 

their hot chocolate is creamy, not too chocolatey, and it's topped with a whipped cream weave and choco sprinkles! no....yes!

free internet, free coffee grounds for the garden (way to reuse), and free access to boardgames!

Personal Anectode... one time i decided to stray from my regular hot chocolate and i ordered an Apple Cider. after i had ordered, they told me they had run out of cider base but in return, they gave me a free coupon for ANY drink! AND a refund! no way!

this place is pretty much thoroughly organic and wholesome (watch out for the coffee cup waste breakdown and the coffee sleeves that encourage you to reuse) - C to the P lives up to its name.
author: Sammy G.

description: These people are great.  They have good coffee and decent foods.  I go here to use my laptop and chit-chat with my coffee buddy.  Kid friendly with a mixed crowd.  Sundays they used to have story hour for kids around 9:30 or 10 with crafts.  Off hours are great with wireless space.  They occassionally screw up my order and have given me a freebee card.  The staff is generally nice though.  The music can be 50-50 (I'm not a Bruce Springsteen fan.)  Bathroom occassionally stinky from local homeless.  It's hard to keep a cap on that, I imagine, because it's in the Haight district.
author: Monikah B.

description: Best vanilla latte I have had. Friendly staff.  Cool hang out area. Coffee refills are ONE DOLLAR. Drink up!
author: Marc D.

description: This is a very nice place, good selection of drinks and coffee cakes, but the staff.. if you are new to this place, no one cares about you at all, everyone looks at you like you're from Pluto or something and acting very unfriendly and even rude. This could be my favorite place, really.. but every time I enter it, I feel soo uncomfortable like these-people-want-me-to-get-out-of-here-now! and even if you just want to check if this drink on the counter is yours (just asking the name of it, nothing more), it seem so hard for these baristas to answer the question, like they don't even know what they just have made.. pity.
author: Ksenia B.

description: Coffee is good, but the wait can be annoying if only one person is working the place.  Friendliness factor is neutral and the political/social statements on the wall could be more creative, although they're interesting.  They do, however, have many tables and spots to sit, which is more than I can say about many other places.  That's a huge plus if you find yourself in the Haight.  It's also nice to see a place truly dedicated to organic and fair trade.
author: marie m.

description: This place has a really nice vibe, great place to surf the web, chat with friends, or just hangout. It is also family friendly. I saw a couple of families with children having breakfast. There are small tables in the front and couple of couches in the back. During busy hours, it's difficult to find a table or a place to sit. About half of the tables were occupied by a person with a laptop and outlets were readily available. The coffee is good; however, my medium latte was $3.50, 50 cents higher than other cafes but the CTTP progressive mission is valid, fair trade, organic, vegan, etc. I will come back Tuesday night for the open mic.
author: Phillip T.

description: Everyone already stated the facts...just wanted to let you know they make a damn good cappuccinio, the foam was perfect!
author: Megan B.

description: In the heart of a city with ultra-conceited coffee shops is a place that pours good strong coffee, has a case full of delicious pastries and savory snacks all with wonderfully friendly baristas. No attitudes, just fast, friendly service!
author: Hotdogger G.

description: I do not live in San Fran (I live in Orange County), but whenever I come to visit my cousin in Haight/Ashbury I come here. I love that there are vegan options, free wifi and a chill atmosphere. It is coffee shops like this that make SF one of my fav cities to visit.
author: Christina A.

description: great chill place, very eco friendly. good coffee, and lots of interestin people to look at. GO GREEN
author: Brad B.

description:
great for coffee, bathroom is a bit yuck, but its ok.

the coffee is great and the people working there are nice.
author: Ruby G.

description:
I am by no means a connoisseur of all things coffee nor do I indulge in coffee so I would say my review is a tad lopsided. 

First off, this place embodies what the Haight represents. Right from the onset, the name of the place itself oozes liberty and justice for all. You make your way in and the ambiance and decor faithfully reinforce its name suggesting that sometimes you can judge a book by its cover. All the insignia and bites of quotes bring out a sense of revolution and critical thought,  spewing out reality checks for daily living while still maintaining a certain aesthetic sense and balance. I felt invigorated walking in prior to even sippin' some joe. Furthermore, Couches,varied and interesting book selections, optimal volume on the music are all well placed additions that maintain its intended vibe. Especially the free wifi totally steals the show and adds to the 'to the people stance' that this place tries to inhabit. Also, the place is fair trade which all the much more appeals and agrees with my sensibilities.

The one thing that I could not however do here was study with focus. If your going here trying to digest technical details and structured information the place is not ideal. Its more suited for the fiction oriented creative outbursts of energy and whimsicality that it probably intends to be. Ofcourse cant expect this place to satisfy my every whim since that is probably only reserved to heaven and lets not forget that this is the Haight were talking about! Overall though, great place to surf and chill and chat and read and I hope these local independents have their own renaissance.

 Been here twice and expect to be a regular. I give it 4 1/2 stars for ambiance and spirit, just wish it took up a lil more real estate. I wish I could tell you more about the coffee but alas this is the full extent of what I can critique.
author: Mallik P.

description: Folks at Coffee to the People are awesome! They are friendly as can be, and they give back to the community in the form of donations of leftovers to the traveling youth who stay for a while and move on or who are seasoned outdoor Haight/Ashbury residents. Thanks for your kind friendship and contributions!
author: S N.

description: jesus christ, the place is fine, but after all these reviews i expected the skies to open and morroccan prostitutes to greet me at the door offering plates of wine and cheese, all while swaying their hips and leading me into a lush pillowed enclave of silk curtains and burning incense. The atmosphere is fine, but nothing special. It's definitely better than muddy waters, but not as good as Revolution Cafe. Plain wood tables and chairs, a few worn couches, free wi-fi, it's decent. And I am SO sick of hearing about their fair trade coffee -- big whoopdeedooda. There are a million places in the city that offer fair trade coffee, for fuck's sake. The meat they serve is not organic OR free-range -- the way workers and the environment (not to mention the animals) are exploited in the meat industry is FAR worse than in the coffee industry. It's lame that people are so quick to embrace the "trendy" social issues, but don't bother with an issue that's not as popular but more important. That's not real activism -- that's pseudo hippy crap. Blech.
author: China Z.

description:
update  09/17/06:
i was contacted by one of the owners of coffee to the people. she was very polite and quite helpful in explaining how coffee to the people gives back to the community. i felt her sincerity, passion and energy in the letter. hence i don't do this very often, but i'm going to increase the rating. three stars for the coffee and one additional star for giving back to the community. thank you, coffee to the people.

this is a segment from her letter:

Here are just a few of the ways that CTTP is different from other coffeeshops:
1) We only serve organic, fair trade coffee. This is better for the environment, better for the health of our customers, and, most important, better for the people who work in the world's coffee fields
2) We pay our employees higher than the San Francisco minimum wage
3) We provide our full-time employees with the opportunity for health insurance
4) We provide our full-time employees with the opportunity to own part of the coffeeshop
5) We allow progressive organizations to use our coffeeshop for events and then provide them with 10% of the total revenue collected during those events
6) Our employees donate a portion of all tips to CoffeeKids--a non-profit organization for helping children in coffee-growing communities
7) We have pledged to donate 10% of all of our profits to nonprofit environmental and social justice organizations (we aren't profitable yet, but we hope to become so sometime in the next year)
8) We provide free coffee for important neighborhood events (e.g. Clean-Up the Haight Day).
.

* * 
original  09/04/06:
um, i don't get the hype here. granted it's probably the best coffee house in the uppper haight, but that's not really saying much. if you compare coffee to the people to say, ritual or blue bottle or peet's, imho, it's infinitely inferior. yeah, you can preach to me about the fair-trade coffee, but even starbucks has fair-trade coffee these days. 

as far as coffee to the people's social awareness is concerned, i'm somewhat confused. so there are social problems around the world. no argument there. however, does coffee to the people actually participate in raising or solving the social issues of the world? just cuz you have a few books about che, marx and engels doesn't make you a champion of the people. now if coffee to the people is using the whole social awareness cause to promote their coffee house and make money, then at best, i find the whole thing gimmickry and at worst, it's another shameless exploitation of the people. kinda like the proliferation of all those che and frida shirts on haight. hence until someone can convince me that coffee to the people does indeed contribute to the cause of the people, i'm giving it two stars.
author: frisco j.

description: So I've heard this place got voted one of the top places to get coffee in SF, even over starbucks.. which I still haven't investigated so I'm not sure if that's entirely true. However this is one of my fav coffee shops in town. On the weekends this place can get very busy but if you get it on more of a slow day this is a chill hang out. I almost always stop here if I am in the haight or even passing through. I have never felt like anyone here was flat out mean but they are a little cold.. consider all the types of people they deal with and see all day every day.. especially in the food service industry it takes a special type of person to be able to deal. (this comes from first hand experience) I have never eatin the food but the coffee is always good.. you would be surprised how many people can f-up a white chocolate mocha these days! If you can get a spot by the window it's the prefect place to people watch while enjoying your coffee or food.
author: Danielle K.

description: Like most other places in the Haight, this place is retro and hip at the same time. The place is great for people-watching, as it's always filled with people working away at all hours of the day. The drinks are good, though I never tried their pastries. The tables can be a little small though, and finding one during the weekends can be tough.
author: Barn M.

description: The coffee and food was good (3.5/5)...but....the customer service was really bad (1/5).  The server/coffee maker was so stuck up (she had a purple bandana on her head), she really needs an attitude adjustment.
author: Cali B.

description: I so hardly expected to see three suits (whom ill call Steve, Jeff and Steve) talking about a golf scorer they can download for their Palm Treo650. And then shift right into a conversation about Belize. Latly, lets dust that delicious social truffle with a quick jeer to someone poor schlub named Mathison from the office that "really dropped the ball on that one." I get my coffee, get my fixins in check, and turn around, and at a different table, there are two REAL hippies from the actual 60's, not some dirtbags bussed in from fucking Marin or Petaluma for a day trip. The real hippies, (whom ill call Professor Smelly and The Reverend Shades) were talking about "getting the newsletter in check, but neither had a computer, cue shared laughter). Finally, a girl on her cell phone (that i will name Miss Britty) arguing with what i assumed was her BFF about how LOL boys were, OMFG. Oh yeah, coffee had some bawls, but they were playing some silly music that sounded like world beats. I really dont like world beats.
author: Mick F.

description: Such good coffee and I don't even feel bad drinking it because it's all free trade! Gigantic, delicious sandwhiches, too. Cranberry scone is so good I ate two. Clean bathroom. Cute barist(os?). Mmm hmm.
author: Bethany D.

description: definitely not much in the way of ambiance, but they're really quick. there's a drink on their specials board that's a chai latte with 4 shots of espresso. it pretty much singlehandedly got me through high school. i don't know what previous viewers are talking about, because the employees here are awesome! they have swipe cards that give you a free tenth drink for every nine you buy. awesome.
author: Jane P.

description: I am lucky enough to call the haight my home for the past year and have been a regular at this place for about that long.  These folks are fantastic, so friendly, nice and none of that stuck up coffeehouse personality,  I really love everyone that works here.  I don't come here to hang out, though I've wanted to spend a lazy afternoon here just playing boardgames, but who has the time?! My boyfriend has had business meetings here and it's served the purpose fine. They have a great "rewards program" where you earn free coffee drinks, and they are so nice to almost always use it on the most expensive item.  Speaking of pricing, they are a bit higher than say, starbucks, but if you are going to starbucks and supporting huge corporations that are sucking the life out of small businesses, you probably wouldn't want to go here anyway.  If you want good fairtrade coffee and amazing pastries from a fantastic local business, come here. save me some orange cranberry loaf though, it's my drug.
author: Holly H.

description: strong cappuccino to start my shopping day at haight st. effective enough to keeping my self alert not to stepping on somebody's pee.
author: sherly A.

description: The grassroots ambiance doesn't prevent these guys from making the best coffee in town (and for a good price).  Well worth my detour when I am in the area.  Try going to Starbucks after this place -- it will make you cry...   Plus they have free wifi and lots of seating.
author: Buckeye W.

description: I like the taste of their white mocha.  The first time they gave it to me was in a big cup.  It's pretty chill and down to earth.  Yes, very "Haight-Ashbury" but as a coffee shop, you could really sit down, do work, and take your laptop.  I'd come back here again!
author: Jen C.

description:
what's with this place?????  i guess if you are a pretntious yuppie hipster or or wholier than thou hippy that recycles your own menstrual blood as compost i'm guessing you probably wouldn't understand the "vibe" ot "the message"  3 bucks for ice tea is criminal unless your supporting the rebels in burma directly which they aren't.  i wish these people would get over themselves.
i'd rather they sold opium and split the profits with greenpeace the burmese peples movement and to stop the war in iraq i would then give this place more stars.  
also... not a certified green restaraunt which if they truly did care about the environment as much as they tout they would look into.  surely the profit margin would not suffer at 3 buck ice teas.  i would then forced to give another star.
author: Anthony Y.

description: Okay, I'm for the most part down with Coffee to the People--the vegan donuts seal the deal--however, the place REALLY needs to work on investing in high(er) quality paper goods. I'm sick of my coffee dripping all over me (and permanently staining various articles of clothing, depending on the trajectory of the drip) because the damn seam on the chintzy paper cup doesn't fit correctly with the lid. Maybe this is part of a larger plot to get all of their coffee-guzzling customers to think hippy-ishly and globally about using reusable travel mugs instead of filling landfills needlessly with one-time-use paper Solo cups. It's a ruthless ploy that has filled me with so much spite that I now refer to the place only as "Coffee to My Butthole."
author: Katherine K.

description: why bother writing a review for a place that already has 99 reviews? i dont know. but i went there today, and i sort of liked it. great  coffee and very nice service. tons of normal people, zombies, and normal zombies. id go back.
author: coffeecake j.

description: they have decently good coffee, the wifi access is great, and there's usually ample seating with comfortable couches and board games.  the only thing i gripe about, and it's not even a quality thing, is the sheer irony of a place calling itself "coffee to the people" while it charges nearly 4 bucks for a blended drink just like any other capitalist coffee house.
author: Khoa N.

description: it's a coffee shop in the Haight, no better but no worse than any other venue vacillating between indifference and pretension. it's staff is typical; individuals who are anything but, with an attitude that reminds me of my adolescence.
author: David D.

description: The Soy Matcha Latte was pretty good. But, this place touts itself as having vegan options. So, it kinda bugged me that after I very specifically ordered "soy", that I was given regular cow milk - luckily I double checked. The guy went to remake it (he was nice about it), and I had to ask for a different cup. Not to be anal, but if I'm trying to not eat animal products, why would I order a soy drink and want to drink it from a cup that had just had cow milk in it? But, here's the rub. It's really futile to try to avoid animal products at this place because they share the espresso machine steamer between soy and cow milk - and - they use the same pitcher to heat up the milks. Then again, this is the case at most coffee places. But...because they go out of the way to advertise their vegan offerings, they should be a bit more aware and sensitive to this. Oh well. The Matcha Latte was pretty good, so 3 stars it is.
author: Maren P.

description:
4 stars because i kept getting kicked off the network.
5 stars cuz it probably wasn't really their fault? and it was free!
3 stars for the impossibility to get into the bathroom.  back up to 5 because that wasn't their fault either.  
4 stars for the prices. back up to 5 cuz am i crazy? it's organic and fair trade coffee! and it's good!  
3 stars- what?! i heard the beginning of a Sublime song and they turned it off!
3.5 stars for the service- at least while they're not taking your order, they're dancing and singing along to the music behind the counter.
5 stars for making soy milk as available as regular milk. 
4 stars for having vegan desserts, but my fault i haven't tried them yet.  i'm stickin' to the -1 star.
0 stars for the loud homeless man that kept sauntering in and out and his entourage of other urniney smelling people
5 stars for overall appearance, art, games, books, couches
4 stars. done and done.
author: Monk R.

description: I was looking for a place with good tea (it was too late for coffee) free wifi and available power outlets, this place had it all, plus the baristas were friendly, and there was a clean bathroom.  I would go back.
author: carrie b.

description: 4 stars for the good concept of the cafe.  i got matcha latte with soy milk.  although i saw a guy putting matcha powder in it, i didnt taste much matcha.  i am japanese and expect a bit of bitterness from matcha in my matcha latte knowing how matcha taste by itself.  maybe they should not use vanilla soy.  i dont think he put sugar in it, but it was sweet (too sweet).  it was not very green either, so maybe matcha powder itself is not good.  my bf had mocha.  it was good, not great or bad.  after reading all the good reviews, maybe our expectation was too high.
author: fat n.

description: i like coffee to the people because a) it's only a few blocks from my apt b) organic coffee and GREAT tea selection c) free wireless. i love their "free speech" decor and you really can concentrate here if you need to read a book or catch up on some work. the music is kind of weird sometimes and they don't have a WIDE food selection, but their sandwiches are huge and above average tasty.
author: bloopie s.

description: best coffee in the haight.  good breakfast sandwiches.  took off one star for stinky druggies begging for change just outside the entrance.
author: Bk G.
